title: 2m rule in place for weeks pubs businesses
story: No said today that the new analysis would take into account incidents of the virus and international comparisons too.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesPubs, bars and restaurants are crying out for the PM to reduce it down to one metre to they can remain viable and stay afloat.The Covid strategy committee - which is chaired by the PM, will look at the evidence on the current two metre rule.The committee will draw on evidence from scientists, but they will make their own decisions.Dominic Raab said this evening that the decision would be underpinned by the science.As we bring the incidents and transmission down, and depending on the setting, [cutting the m rule] is something that is going to be looked at, he added.We expect the review to be completed in the coming weeks, and we will have more to say then.He repeated that pubs and hospitality is not expected to open until July , and added: The review of the m rule will inform that.The PM has previously said he would get the review completed by today, when shops across the country have reopened to customers.A spokesperson for the PM said today: It will look at evidence around transmission of the virus, incidence rates, and in dferent environments, and international comparisons. It will draw on advice from scientic and medical experts as well as economists and papers from SAGE. It will take advice from a range of experts including the Chief Medical Officer and the Chief Scientic Adviser.It will be completed in the coming weeks.Cutting down the risk from two to one metre would crease ten times extra risk of catching coronavirus, experts say.But other studies show that the dference is marginal.The PM has said he wants to cut it when the number of incidents of the virus reduces - which would mean there would be a slimmer chance of catching it anyway.The review will be led by Simon Case- the permanent secretary at No.The PMs spokesperson confirmed that the opening date for pubs and hospitality businesses is still from July  meaning that there is just over two weeks to go.They said: We understand that they will want to get going again as soon as they possibly can.But we have a duty to ensure that when reopening does take place, its done in a safe way. But there is not yet confirmation that the July  reopening will yet go ahead. It could also be the case that pubs open with m social distancing in place and the rule reduces to one just weeks afterwards, sparking chaos for businesses.The British Beer  Pub Association , the leading trade association representing Britain’s brewers and pubs, has today demanded the UK Government give a clear date for when pubs can reopen.  Emma McClarkin, Chief Executive of the British Beer  Pub Association, told The Sun: If the Government can help in any way to go to a safe distance, as advised WHO, that will help our sector reopen.We need to know, it’s having a major impact on our preparations. We need to get clarity, immediately.Our pub are burning money - for every moment they remain closed –they are have to remain closed or they are not viable, they are burning away up to £m a month.The longer we have this waiting or preication on any decision making, the more likely it will be tens of thousands of job losses, and pubs will close their doors for good.Kevin Georgel, Chief Executive of St Austell Brewery, said: Like many other breweries we have been forced to take a signicant gamble and start brewing draught beer again to ensure that pubs can reopen on th July as per the Government roadmap. Cask Ale on average takes three weeks to brew and lager can often take longer. In order for pubs to be able to serve a pint of fresh draught beer that customers have longed for during lockdown, we had to start brewing last week. If pubs do not now open on th July, all of this beer will be lost at huge cost to us during this time of survival.The news comes after reports that the Governments top scientists were unhappy about having to shoulder the responsibility for the decision, and the Sunday Times claimed they were on resignation watch.The Government has repeatedly said it will be led by the science in making decisions about the coronavirus outbreak.Number  insisted there was not an issue in the Governments relations with the scientists who appear at the daily coronavirus press conferences.Last week the Governments Chief Scientic Adviser, Patrick Vallance said last week that the two metre advice was not a rule.He told the Downing Street briefing last week: “It is wrong to portray this as a scientic rule that says it is two metres or nothing – that is not what the advice has been and it is not what the advice is now.”Instead the decision is going to be taken by ministers, the Chancellor confirmed yesterday.It means it will be up to Boris to make the final decision. He has been told there is no magic number of infections to get down to before its safe to reduce the m rule.The World Health Organisation says at least one metre apart is recommended. Other countries in Europe have reduced their distances to .m or even one.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: four ex education secretaries free school meals plea
story: Ed Balls, David Blunkett, Estelle Morris and Alan Johnson have all signed a letter warning children without adequate internet access could never catch up. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesFormer PM Tony Blair also signed the letter, started by Rashford, the Manchester United and England hero, which said there are at least , disadvantaged children who dont have access to computers or internet. They called on the Government to provide free school meals throughout the summer holidays to stop .million kids from going hungry. Free meal support was extended to Easter break and half term to help those kids struggling the most by giving them £ vouchers. The letter said: Access to the internet and technology has been vital during the lockdown.It has enabled many households to remain in contact with friends and family, to take part in online exercise classes, and to continue learning and studying despite the closure of schools. But this leline has not been available for all, with schools across the country reporting struggling families who do not have internet access at home. Some children have been allowed toto school - with primary schools reopening for small groups of pupils in reception, year one and year six, and secondary schools opening today for children in year  and year . But Britains most deprived children are at risk of falling years behind their peers as school closures made pre-existing inequalities even worse. According to figures by the Sutton Trust, cited by the letter, in the most deprived schools  per cent of teachers said more than  third of their students dont have adequate access to computers or internet. A spokesperson for No said: The PM will respond to Marcus Rashford’s letter as soon as he can. He has been using his profile in a positive way to highlight some v important issues.The Prime Minister understand the issues facing families in the UK - the Government announced an extra £million for local authorities to benefit all families who are struggling to afford food and other basic essentials. Chairman of the Education Select Committee Robert Halfon told The Dailythere could be an educational ice age for deprived kids who missed out on the full scope of virtual learning. Rashford wrote to the Government pleading for extra help for hungry children. He wrote: “The Government has taken a ‘whatever it takes’ approach to the economy - I’m asking you today to extend that same thinking to protecting all vulnerable children across England.“I encourage you to hear their pleas and find your humanity. Please reconsider your decision to cancel the food voucher scheme over the summer holiday and guarantee the extension.“This is England in , and this is an issue that needs urgent assistance.“Please, while the eyes of the nation are on you, make the U-turn and make protecting the lives of some of our most vulnerable a top priority.”Rashford previously revealed how his family relied on breakfast clubs and free school meals as a child, and does not want other children to miss out.A spokesperson for the Department for Education saidfree school meals would not be given out during the holidays. They said: As schools open more widely, and their kitchesn reopen, we expect schools to make food parcels available for collection or delivery for any children that are eligible for free school meals who are not yet able toto school. Free school meals are ordinarily term-time only, and the national voucher scheme will not run during the summer holidays. However, as announced this week by the Prime Minister, the local authority welfare assistance scheme will provide help to those who are struggling to afford food and other essentials due to the impacts of COVID-.  To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: influencer blasted squats skimpy swimsuit yards hindu ceremony bali
story: Posing up a storm at the beach for a pals photos, her ignorance and bad manners were blasted on social media for showing she didnt give a f***.Balis beaches remain officially closed to stop the spread of coronavirus, but some visitors are still flouting rules, reports Coconuts.It said that Canggu-based Instagram account @thecanggupole uploaded a clip showing the religious gathering feet away from the vain influencer.Labelling the video Ignorancers in the wild, it quickly racked up thousands of views, and derogatory comments.One replied: The amount of disrespect... and f***s not given.Another said: Is it that hard to respect a culture that open to everyone seriously! Come on f*** those squats.Others chipped in to say it was disrespectful on so many levels.And one dubbed the influencer and her pals dirty white trash.Canggu is a resort village on the south coast of the Indonesian island, boasting yoga studios, hipster cafes and beach bars, according to tourist websites.Balinese women in traditional clothing can be seen in the video giving offerings during the poignant beachside ceremony.Meanwhile, the camera pans to the blonde beachgoer, oblivious to the religious ceremony, while performing deep squats close to a sitting dog.News.au reports that the woman was just steps away from a Canang sari - daily offerings made by Balinese Hindus to thank the Sang Hyang Widhi Wasa in praise and prayers.One person wrote of the video: Only caring about themselves.“This is inappropriate,” another commented, adding, “time and a place for everything and that ain’t it.”Indonesia’s tropical holiday island of Bali could reopen to tourists in October, the government said last month.In March, a -year-old British woman hospitalised in Bali died from Covid-, Indonesia’s first recorded death from the disease, officials said back then.Suspicion over an apparent initial lack of cases in Indonesia grew when a Chinese tourist who had travelled to Bali from Wuhan tested positive for the coronavirus when he ed to China in early February.Indonesian authorities played down the event, with Defence Minister Muhammad Mahfud declaring in February: “The coronavirus does not exist in Indonesia.”There have been about  confirmed cases of the killer bug in Bali. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl foot beach barbecue
story: Lola Thomasson, seven, was chasing after a ball on Avon Beach in Dorset, when the four-inch stick impaled the sole of her foot on Friday.Mum Karen Krige rushed her to the hospital with the skewer still in her foot.It was removed at Christchurch Hospital after a four-hour ordeal.Ms Krige said when she inspected the area on the the beach afterwards she found a handful of skewers and hot coals partially buried in the sand.She has since begged beachgoers to put their rubbish in the bin so others dont have to suffer like her daughter.Ms Krige, , said: It was a nightmare day. We wanted to go down to see the stone display, do some crabbing and see our friends in their beach hut.We hadnt been there for long when Lola and her friend Bethany were running chasing a ball when the next thing we knew Lola was on the ground screaming.I ran over to her and phoned for an ambulance when I saw her foot.But after an hour it had still not come so I carried her for  minutes back to the car and drove to the hospital.The way the skewer pierced Lolas foot makes me think it was stuck into the sand upright.They gave her gas and air in hospital and finally removed the skewer after four hours before bandaging up her foot.It was a traumatic experience for Lola and the worst thing is now she doesnt want to go to the beach again.The mum said shes been left frustrated after she picked up other beachgoers rubbish. She added: Its so frustrating as residents and beach hut owners are seeing whats happening to our beaches.I cleaned up the area and as well as skewers there were hot coals buried in the sand. It was shocking.In the hospital, Lola said when I have an ice lolly I always put the stick in the bin, why didnt they put it in the bin.I just hope there are no more incidents like this.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain left out summer
story: Brussels launched a new website and app today showing people across the continent where they can get away for a break. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt includes key info from holiday hotspots like Spain, Portugal, Italy, and Greece loaded onto an interactive map.  But Brits are left in the dark about restrictions they may face because were not included. The initiative, called Re-open EU, is the central pillar of the blocs drive to get people travelling again. A Commission spokesman claimed the UK hadnt asked to be involved in the scheme - but can still apply to take part. They added other non-EU countries like Norway and Switzerland already have and should soon be added to the site. The revelation will be a blow to Brits hoping to jet off abroad and domestic tourism businesses keen to welcome back visitors from Europe.To take part in the scheme governments have to provide regular updates about which measures they have in place to tackle the pandemic. The map provides real-time info on how easy it is to travel to inidual countries and which restrictions like quarantine requirements are in place. It also has national details about whether hotels and attractions like shops, bars, restaurants, beaches, and museums are open. And it contains advice on local rules covering the wearing of face masks, social distancing, contact tracing app, and pre-travel testing. Brussels internal market boss Thierry Breton said: “After weeks of confinement, EU internal borders are reopening. The Re-open EU website will provide travellers with easy access to information to help them confidently make their travel plans and stay safe during their trip. It will also help small restaurant and hotel owners, as well as towns across Europe, draw inspiration from innovative solutions developed by others.”No  yesterday revealed that not a single person has been fined so far for breaking the UKs quarantine rules. The PMs spokesman said: Were not aware of anyone refusing to provide their details when asked to do so. He added work on air bridge deals with EU countries is ongoing and said: We all want to see the UK open up for travel as soon as its safe to do so.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus oxford street london shops reopen
story: Londons Oxford Street – which has seen off the Blitz and the Great Depression – lurched back into le with queues of eager shoppers forming outside major outlets before am.Europe’s busiest shopping street - eerily quiet for months – was full of laughter and hubbub once more as non-essential shops opened for the first time since March.Some bargain hunters allowed their excitement to get the better of them as they barged and shoved in a queue for Nike trainers as social distancing temporality went out the window.But for the most part, families – emerging from months of lockdown –  observed safety rules as they could finally indulge in some much-needed retail therapy in blazing c sunshine.Nurses Christina Doohan and Sarah Dillany, both , who work at Great Ormond Street Hospital, were laden with shopping bags.“It’s great to be able to go shopping again,” said Christina. “Hopefully this will be a bit of a lt for people.”First in the queue of around  people at Sports Direct’s flagship Oxford Street store was Michelle Gallagher, , from Angel, north London.The Maternity Support Worker at Westminster and Cha Hospital told The Sun: “This is my first time out apart from work and going to the supermarket. You have to be careful and take the necessary precautions but it’s great to be able to go to the shops again.”Michelle – who was wearing a protective mask – added: “We’ve been queuing since .am because they’re doing  per cent discounts for NHS workers, so we’re hoping for some bargains.”Her partner Elliot Batt, ,  added: “If there’s stuff I like, I’m going to buy it. Trainers, T-shirts, whatever.Next in the queue, students Lizzie Nsinba and Rena Morena, both , from Lambeth, south London, had already been to nearby Primark.Rena explained: “It’s so good to be out shopping at last after so long in lockdown.The store has hand sanitiser stations, a one-way system, Perspex shielding at the tills and frequent cleaning of touch points.Staff – who have a choice of wearing visors and masks - allow a maximum of  shoppers in at one time. Staff sterilise trainers that shoppers try on then don’t buy.Footwear manager Rehad Ahmed, , said: “My we Mahnaz is a vulnerable person with a heart condition but I feel very safe working here and have reassured her.“The training Ive received has been crystal clear and we’ve got all the PPE.”General manager Dhiren Patel, , said: “We are  per cent confident we can deliver safe shopping.“Shoppers are doing what we tell them and observing the new rules.”Around the corner at Nike Town social distancing went awry as dozens of shoppers pushed and shoved to get to the front of the queue snaking up Regent Street before staff restored order.An eyewitness told the Evening Standard: “It was mainly ‘lads’ pushing at the front. Shoving each other.There were some fists. There were maybe  people here in line before am.”Long queues had formed with shoppers desperate to snap up limited edition Nike Air Jordan  High Zoom trainers, which can cost up to £ and have sold out online.Tom Jackson, , told MailOnline: “The problem is that people have been pushing in. We’ve seen a few people jump the queue at the front, which isn’t really fair. It’s been a bit chaotic to be honest. I’m not very impressed.”Queuing to buy trainers, shopper Ricky Young, , was askedhe had expected the first shopping morning to be so busy.No, I actually thought people might have been sleeping or didnt want to go out, he revealed.Nearby, Izzy Froude, , was busy marking out social distance spacing with plastic sticky strips on the pavement outside Urban Outfitters.Izzy, the display coordinator for the store, said: “I was up here on Saturday and it was so quiet but today its been fairly busy . It’ll take time to get back to normal  but today is very promising.”The UK economy shrank by more than a fth in the first full month of lockdown and shops are desperate to offload £bn of unsold stock.Jace Tyrrell, chief executive at New West End Company, said there had been an easing in for shoppers.The head of the partnership of  retail, restaurant, hotel and property owners in Londons West End said: The businesses that have opened have a nice customer trade coming in, people are queuing, which is very good.Of course it is day one and weve got quite a few months of this ahead of us.He said the West End is expected to have  per cent fewer people than usual without hordes of tourists and shop workers.Appealing to shoppers, he said: Youll never have the West End like it. So come out, dont rush out, weve got weeks like this.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: one in five kids no schoolwork
story: It comes as ministers sparked fresh fury tonight after announcing millions of teens will only get one meeting with their teacher in six months.The UCL study found a staggering . million children across the UK are hardly doing any schoolwork at all in the lockdown.Nationally, kids are spending on average just . hours a day working – around half of what was previously thought.The schools shutdown is “tragically” fuelling educational ides, with poor kids and those in the North East losing out most, researchers said.But it is a “threat” to the education and le chances of an entire generation of kids, the study found.Tory MP Robert Halfon, boss of the education select committee, said: “We have got to get our children learning again.“These children, particularly the younger ones, are missing out on the most important parts of their lives and we are damaging their le chances in a huge way.“We need to get these kids back on the educational ladder of opportunity.”Professor Francis Green, the study’s lead author, said it paints a “gloomy picture of lost schooling”.He said:  “Everyone is losing out in this generation, some much more than others.“Better home schoolwork provision, and better still an early safeto school for as many as possible, should now become a top priority for government.”The study of , children, found massive regional and class ides in the amount of schoolwork kids are doing in the lockdown.Children from London, the South and the East of England and in Northern Ireland spend the most time on their schoolwork, kids in the North and Wales the least.Children on free school meals are missing out the most, the study found.Just  per cent of kids on free school meals are getting four bits of offline work to do a day, compared to  per cent of kids not on them.While one in five free school meal children do not have access to a computer at home causing “considerable harm” to their studies in the lockdown.Just  per cent of other children don’t have a computer.Private school kids are missing out the least, with  per cent getting four or more lessons a day compared with just  per cent in state story: The London Mayor said earlier that they will become the norm rather than the exception for months to come.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt came on the same day as wearing masks on all public transport became mandatory.Anyone going on a train, tube, bus, ferry or plane must cover their face up.If they refuse, they could be denied entry onto public transport, or face a £ fine.Mr Khan told LBC tonight:This is part of the new normal.For the forseeable future, I believe for the next year or so, wearing face coverings is going to become the norm rather than the exception.I was pleased when the PM accepted the need for us to wear face coverings on public transport, and make it mandatory.Its one of the most unselfish things you can do.Not only is that sensible health-wise, but it gives people confidence they are not going to catch the virus, and shop safely.The Mayor had been pushing for people to wear masks on transport before the Government announced it would become compulsory. The Government has said they will keep the face coverings rules under review - title: commuters wear masks compulsory public transport coronavirus
story: Brits pulled on the face coverings as they got on trains and Tubes this morning to stop the spread of the deadly bug.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesCommuters were this morning pictured at Waterloo station wearing masks as they headed back to work.British Transport Police will have the power to fine rule breakers £they fail to wear the safety precautions.And BTP today tweeted out a reminder to Brits to make sure they wear the masks - with the items being handed out at many stations to make sure people are following the rules.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps announced that from June  it will be mandatory for people to wear face coverings on public transport.This includes on trains, buses, trams, ferries and aircraft.Masking the mouth and nose reduces the risk of asymptomatic carriers — people who are infected but showing no symptoms — from passing on the bug.A DIY face-covering can be used — even just a scarf or a thin cloth mask.Railway staff will also adopt the mask-wearing guidelines.But the Government has warned that for face coverings to be effective, people must wash their hands before putting them on and taking them off.The government is asking people to use a simple face covering, and not buy up PPE standard medical masks as they still are needed for the NHS.Private hire taxis and minicabs are also included in the ­measures, but the rules do not cover bus stops, railway stations and other terminals.Anyone not wearing a mask will be kicked off unless they are disabled, young children or have breathing dficulties.Face coverings are now also compulsory in hospitals, with staff, visitors and outpatients required to wear them.Mr Shapps said that it would be an England-only rule, but he expects that Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will follow suit.He said: You can be refused travelyou dont comply and you could be fined.The Department of Health said previously, after considering the latest scientic advice from SAGE, that face coverings can help reduce the spread of Covid-.They stressed that the evidence shows face coverings can stop you passing coronavirus on to others,you are asymptomatic or have yet to develop symptoms.A new German study last week showed that the compulsory use of facemasks slows the spread of coronavirus by  per cent.The study was able to use the staggered introduction of masks in shops and on public transport across Germany as a natural experiment to test how effective the masks were.Looking at the new cases in the days that followed the experiment, scientists found that there is “strong and convincing statistical support” that the masks “strongly reduced the number of incidences”. Scientists have even suggested that wearing face masks might protect against coronavirus better than handwashing or social distancing.But some scientists criticised the mandatory use of face masks on the grounds that there was still no evidence that masks helped stop the spread of the virus.Other groups argue that without strong evidence, there was a clear plausible mechanism for how even homemade cloth masks could stop onward transmission You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailNon-essential shops and zoos reopen from Monday  June in England as the economy slowly creaks back into le. For the first time in three months youaposll be able to go clothes shopping and see the lemurs. But there will be strict social distancing rules in place and firms will be ordered to carry out more hygiene measures than usual. Expect queues outside shops and high demand for tickets for attractions allowed to reopen. Meanwhile, people who live alone or single parents are allowed to form a bubble with one other household in England. This means breaking the two-metre rule for the first time to hug and kiss, share childcare, stay the night and have sexthataposs your thing. Hereaposs everything you need to know about the lockdown changes this week. Two separate households in England can now join together in a “support bubble” under certain conditions. They won’t need to follow the two-metre rule - meaning they can hug, kiss, share childcare and meals, hang out indoors, stay the night and even have sex for the first time since March . One of the two households in each bubble must be a “single-adult household”. This means either a person who lives alone, or a single parent who lives with children under . There’s an incredible £million of funding from The National Lottery being shared among good causes around the UK – and it’s all thanks to you. Le’s been harder than ever for young carers in lockdown. But charities like TEN North East are offering vital support thanks to National Lottery funding. Program lead Levi Cosker  says: One mother calls our project a leline – without us she wouldn’t have any support. Click here to read her amazing full story. Visit national-lottery news to learn more about how you’re helping. The other household they are joining with can be of any size, and can have more than one adult in it. However, in total each bubble must only consist of two households - and each household must keep the arrangement “exclusive”. That means a person living alone cannot form multiple bubbles with multiple households. Likewise, a family cannot form multiple bubbles with more than one lonely relative. For a full explanation and QA click here. What changes in England from June  Non-essential shops reopen  Non-essential shops will be allowed to reopen for the first time for almost three months in England. Stories will need strict social distancing measures, much like those weaposve already seen in supermarkets and other essential stores. Brands vowing to reopen bang on time from June  include Primark, GAME, Debenhams, O, EE and BT, HM, Lush, GAME, H Samuel and Argos. John Lewis is set to open most stores from June , while Next will open a handful followed by others in the coming weeks. Types of shop allowed to reopen include:Fashion shops Charity shops Betting shops and arcades Tailors, dress fitters and fashion designers Auction houses Antique stores Retail art galleries Photography studios Gt shops and retail spaces in theatres, museums, libraries, heritage sites and tourism sites Mobile phone stores Craft fairsFace coverings will be mandatory on public transport  Everyone travelling on public transport in England will be required to wear a face covering from June . Wearing a face covering - not a surgical mask - will be part of the conditions of carriage for travelling on public transport. That means travellers could be refused permission to board buses or trainsthey refuse to comply with the order. Serious offenders could be fined, but ministers have claimed people will largely comply and this wonapost be needed.  Hospital visitors and staff will need to wear face coverings and masks All hospital visitors and outpatients in England will be required to wear face coverings - while all hospital staff will be required to wear higher-grade, type  or  surgical masks. Zoos, safari parks and drive-in cinemasstart to re-open  Zoos, safari parks and drive-in cinemas are set to reopen in England from Monday. Boris Johnson has said they can reopen as long as they follow social distancing rules. That means their on-site cafes and restaurants are expected to operate as take-away only. Only outdoor attractions are allowed to reopen, so reptile houses and indoor aquariums will remain closed. Sites will be operating at reduced capacity, and there may be one-way systems in place. And of course, because very few things are likely to be open it will be busy, you should book your ticket online in advance to ensure youaposre not disappointed when you turn up. Churches reopen but only for private prayer  Places of worship reopen in England from June , but only for private prayer and not for services. Iniduals are expected to be able to reflect and pray while adhering to social-distancing rules - but worship groups, weddings and other services will still not be permitted. In line with government guidance churches will be expected to be deep-cleaned regularly and should remove shared books from public areas. Churches have been closed since  March, following instructions from the Government. School pupils in Years  and a quarter at a time  Secondary schools in England can reopen for Years  and  from June , but not all students will be allowed toat the same time. Only a quarter of eligible pupils will be allowed in school at any one time - meaning schools have had to instigate special timetables and classes to make the system work. Secondary schools are not likely to fully reopen until September at the earliest. Students who dowill be encouraged to travel separately and avoid public transport. The teaching of vulnerable children and those of critical workers in all year groups will continue until the start of the summer holidays. Some primary schools will open a bit further than they are now While around half of the UKaposs primary schools have been open to more pupils from June , some have remained closed to all but key workersapos kids. This meant nursery, reception, year one and year six pupils in some parts of the country havenapost yet got back into the classroom. Some places, like Doncaster and Liverpool, stopped schools reopening on June , but will see them reopening their doors on Monday. Donapost expect more big changes to primary school attendance before September though. Plans for all pupils in Years , ,  and  tofor a month before the summer break in England have been dropped by Education Secretary Gavin Williamson. Instead schools are just being asked to bring back whoever they can, depending on capacity. He told MPs he is now aiming to get all children back to school in September,possible. What has already changed in recent weeks in EnglandJune : Primary schools were asked to reopen to years R,  and  in England - though only about half of them actually did June : People allowed to meet in socially-distanced groups of up to  outdoors, including in private gardens June : Car showrooms and outdoor markets allowed to reopen June : Dentists begin to reopen with extra hygiene measures in place June : -day quarantine comes into forced for those arriving in the UK June : Some parking charges that were suspended . What weaposll still need to wait until July for - or longer Pubs, restaurants and bars Pubs, restaurants, bars and cafes are not expected to reopen in England until July  at the earliest. They can already operate as takeaways - good news for pubs next to parks or beaches - but they canapost have people drinking on the premises, even in the beer garden. Pubs arenapost guaranteed to reopen on July  - thataposs just the starting date for the hospitality and leisure industry so boozers might come later. When they do open itaposll have to be with social distancing rules in place. Hairdressers and nail bars  Hairdressers, barbers and beauty salons are also only opening from July  at the earliest. And like pubs, the date could end up being later because itaposs hard to avoid being in close contact with someone cutting your hair. The two-metre rule Boris Johnson is under pressure to drop the two-metre social distancing rule down to one metre or one and a half. This would increase the risk of catching the virus from someone but allow the economy to restart. The government has made clear that the two-metre rule is still in all its guidance, including draft rules for pubs and cafes to reopen. But that could change in future. Boris Johnson has said he wants to cut the distance but only when itaposs supported by the science. In basic terms, that means waiting until your overall risk from catching the virus in wider society is so low, some extra risk from the person youaposre next to is acceptable. Scientists say youaposre  to  times more at risk from one metre away than two metres away. Wider school reopenings

Here, she explains how...A couple of weeks after lockdown started, I found myself on the other side of London in a housing estate I didn’t know, trying to find a young woman I had never met before. She was a refugee, pregnant, alone and living in temporary accommodation. It was pouring with rain and I was standing in a stairwell as, in broken English, she was trying to explain over the phone how I could find her. When I finally got to her doorstep, I couldn’t even smile at her because I was wearing a face mask. And social distancing rules meant I couldn’t go in to sit down, have a cup of tea and explain the things in the box I was bringing her, as I would do normally. But as she stood in her doorway, I could tell she was really excited.  Hours later, we received a text message. It said how happy and delighted she was with the things we had brought her – that now she finally felt ready to have her baby, which she hadn’t before. It was such a moving moment.We normally have a core group of  volunteers, but since coronavirus it has just been me and my daughter Rosa, , running everything. So we decided to concentrate on baby boxes for newborns. They contain a sling, a steriliser and a breast pump as well as baby clothes, nappies, wet wipes, nappy cream and hygiene stuff for the mother. We’ve even started putting in a couple of loo rolls. It has been a struggle, but we have been helped enormously by National Lottery funding. And because lockdown has made it dficult to accept donations, where necessary we have also been able to afford a few bits to put in the boxes. The grant from The National Lottery has been a leline for us, allowing us to keep giving out our boxes which, in turn, the mothers say are their leline. Meanwhile, in Kent, another National Lottery-funded project, Youth Sports Trust, is tackling a problem facing young people - fitness and staying connected with friends... Sport is keeping kids connected  Teacher Guy Wilkins works closely with children’s charity Youth Sport Trust to enable children and young people to access competitive sport, training opportunities and learning leadership skills - and lockdown hasnapost put a stop to that. The -year-old, from Kentaposs Marjorie McClure School, said: During lockdown we’ve been running online meetings, setting physical challenges and sharing ideas for PE at home - such as ‘washing line tennis’ - to bring people even closer together. Many of us also got involved with the charity . challenge. For example, one of our students, James,  – who is a massive Crystal Palace fan – did  keepy-uppies.” Jamesaposs mum Wendy said the charity has been a vital link to the outside world for her son - and he has loved embracing the challenges. She told us: James has really benefited from having regular Zoom calls from school with his form tutor and Guy, as well as Tom who runs the after school cricket club which James attends.  James loves to have a look at these ideas and try out as many as he can. They suggested that the pupils try the daily Joe Wicks sessions as a fitness challenge and heaposs ended up doing them most days. The school challenged the pupils to take part in the . challenge so James ran walked .km and made a donation to the Bromley Mencap charity. Guy’s school – which is one of a network of six YST inclusive schools across South London – receives up to £, of National Lottery funding each year. This money helps to pay for leadership opportunities, give young people training to increase self esteem, confidence and communication skills, and the opportunity to experience badminton, volleyball, wheelchair basketball and athletics at inclusive sports festivals.They will also be taking part in YST’s National School Sport Week at Home, taking place from  to  June. You can find out more about it here.Back in London, The Science Museum has come up with its own idea for getting people involved - by putting many of its amazing artacts online... Science Museum fans flock online  Natasha McEnroe is the Science Museumaposs Keeper of Medicine. She explained: “The first year of opening for the Science Museumaposs new aposMedicine: The Wellcome Galleriesapos hasn’t at all been what I envisaged. “We were only open for five months before we had to close, and it was especially sad because we’d been lucky enough to have glowing press and visitor feedback.“Since lockdown we’ve been focusing on really pushing our digital delivery - which you can explore here . We are working on our oral history programme and - as part of a larger digitisation project, we’re photographing more than , objects from our collections – from space suits to Tracy the transgenic sheep. There’s also a very extensive  blog  and  learning resources and going online makes everything accessible to a much wider audience. “Some of our most searched items have been pieces including historic hospital ventilators.” The newly-opened Medicine Galleries - which were part funded by an £million grant from The National Lottery Heritage Fund - have proved a huge hit since moving online. In April, online visits to the Science Museum Group’s learning resources increased by % over an average month, with visits to the online collection in May breaking all previous records.

second lowest increase since the lockdown began in March. In hospitals England reported  new deaths, and Wales recorded four more. There were no new deaths reported in Northern Ireland or Scotland in hospital settings. Non-essential shops in England reopened today after  weeks of being shut. Major names opening some of their stores include Apple, Argos, Curryaposs, PC World, HM, House of Fraser and Lush. Photographs outside reopened Primark stores showed huge queues of eager shoppers - one seen donning a full bodysuit of personal protective equipment. Any business reopening must demonstrate that it is compliant to customers and businesses who fail to comply by the rules will face harsh penalties. Meanwhile, people who live alone or single parents are allowed to form a bubble with one other household in England. For more of the latest updates throughout today, follow our LIVE blog, below to get the Mirror’s daily coronavirus briefing email at  mirror email  -after the press conference every evening. Key EventsDeath toll from coronavirus hits , after  people die:British embassy confirms Brits can travel to Spain from June :UK hospital death toll rises by  in second lowest increase since lockdown:Scotland records no new deaths in the last  hours:Woman spotted in full bodysuit of PPE as queues force Primark to reopen early::Critics say government moving away from expert adviceCritics have accused the Government of a #xCdeliberate move away from expert advice#xD after the Foreign Secretary took the daily press conference on Monday without any science or medical chiefs present. The Liberal Democrats#x health spokeswoman Munira Wilson said: #xCThe image of the Foreign Secretary standing alone at the press conference was stark. #xCWe have seen over the past week a deliberate move away from expert advice and transparency at the daily press conferences.#xCIt is absolutely crucial that people have faith in the Government through their handling of the coronavirus crisis, particularly as the lockdown is eased and people come into more contact with each other.#xD:No new Covid- deaths in IrelandThere have been no new deaths of people with Covid- reported in Ireland.The overall death toll there remains unchanged at ,, the National Public Health Emergency Team said.A man wearing a protective face mask passes a pub in Dublin, Ireland :At least  out of  Tube users wearing face coveringAround four out of five Tube and bus users in London wore a face covering on Monday as they became mandatory on public transport in England, the city#xs transport commissioner said. Mike Brown said that the response of passengers had #xCexceeded my expectations#xD after the new rule was announced on June . He said: #xCMore than %is what we#xre seeing in observations. #xCIn some places it#xs higher, %-%. #xCCertainly quite a signicant uptake. #xCFor the first day, I#xm really pleased the way passengers are responding as I would have expected them to do so.#xD More than , additional staff from British Transport Police, Network Rail, train operators and Transport for Londonare being deployed at major stations and transport hubs to ensure the new rules are being followed.A man wearing a protective face mask walks past signage advising the use of face coverings, near Tower Bridge, London :Relaxation of m rule will be underpinned by scienceDominic Raab insisted a decision on whether to reduce the two-metre rule would be #xCunderpinned#xD by science.The Foreign Secretary told the Downing Street press conference: #xCThere#xs no magic to one or other particular measure, there will be dferent levels of risk whether it#xs at two metres, one-and-a-half metres or one metre. #xCAs we bring the incidence and the transmission rate down, depending on the setting, it#xs something that can be looked at. #xCWe are still going to make sure that all of the policy judgments that we rightly as politicians take and are accountable for are underpinned by the science.#xD :More research needed into coronavirus risk to BAME communitiesThe Foreign Secretary said more research was needed before Public Health England findings into the risk posed by Covid- to black, Asian and minority ethniccommunities could be released. When asked why the Government had not published the report, which was leaked last week, Dominic Raab said: #xCWe do want to get to the bottom of that, we#xve commissioned more research on it.#xCI think you#xd agree that needs to be handled very sensitively but we are making sure we get to the bottom of it and that we#xve got a clear view before we advise the public.#xD Pressed on why it was not being published immediately, Mr Raab added: #xCIt is not right, this subject is sensitive where we have not got to the bottom of all the evidence to start leaking snippets out.#xCWe want to make sure we#xve got a clearer understanding so we can communicate it with practical advice for those involved, precisely because it is a very sensitive issue and we want to give clear and reassuring guidance and not to have dferent people saying dferent things. #xCWe will release as much evidence as we can as soon as we practically can.#xD:Pubs could reopen with marquees, face coverings and screens between tables, minsters hintPubs in England could reopen with screens between tables, compulsory face coverings and marquees to allow more outdoor seats, ministers hinted today.A minister also said roads could shut to allow outdoor seating, pedestrianisation and more #xCtemporary markets#xD to get the high street back on its feet.Two ministers dished a buffet of possibilities in Parliament as they tried to quell a Tory revolt over the two-metre social distancing rule.The PM has launched a review that could see it cut to one metre or . metres - and will listen to economists, not just experts on coronavirus.But Tory MPs are angry after he only promised to finish it in #xCthe coming weeks#xD - despite pubs hoping to reopen in England from July .Today Health Minister Edward Argar told the House of Commons: #xCThe current scientic advice is the two-metre rule signicantly reduces the risk of transmission and we have not yet beaten this disease.#xDRead the full story here.Pubs may be able to open with strict distancing guidelines in place :Government has taken careful approach to reopening economy, Raab saysForeign Secretary Dominic Raab said the Government had to take a careful approach to reopening the economy. At the Downing Street press conference, he said: #xCWe can#xt just pretend coronavirus has gone away and we have eliminated the virus. #xCWe know from the science, and also what we are seeing from international experience, that there is a risk of a second spikewe are not very careful at this moment of time. #xCSo we need to keep up the social distancing, we need to keep building up and reinforcing the test and trace regime and we need to continue our steady progress in repressing the virus as we try to get le back to something like normal.#xD The Foreign Secretary speaking at Downing Street today:Jaguar Land Rover to cut over , jobsCarmaker Jaguar Land Rover is set to cut up to , temporary jobs from its factory floors as the company deals with the fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. JLR reported a #xA million loss in the final quarter of its financial year as it lost nearly a third of its sales over the three months. #xCAgainst the backdrop of the Covid- pandemic, the company has taken the dficult decision to reduce the number of contract-agency employees in its manufacturing plants over the coming months,#xD the company said in a statement.:Dominic Raab at todays Downing Street briefingDominic Raab is speaking at today#xs Downing Street briefing, but did not have scientic advisors alongside him in a break from tradition.He confirmed the coronavirus death toll is now , after a further  people died.Dominic Raab:Minister considering outdoor seating and road closures to boost high streetMore outdoor seating, closing roads to cars and allowing marquees outside pubs are steps being considered to boost the high street, the Communities Secretary has said. Robert Jenrick outlined his ambitions for revitalising shopping areas while also confirming he will announce #xCshortly#xD the Government#xs #xCcomprehensive plan#xD to ensure councils have #xCfinancial stability for the remainder of this year#xD in light of Covid-.Speaking in the Commons, Mr Jenrick said: #xCHelping our towns and cities to develop safe trading environments, particularly on high streets, is vital to this Government#xs efforts to kick-start our economy, get people back to work and get businesses trading again. #xCWe continue to examine all the options to revitalise our high streets. #xCI want to spark a vibrant cafe culture to support hospitality businesses, making it easier for them to operate outdoors with seating and tables, for temporary markets to set up and for the streets to be temporarily pedestrianised. #xCMany councils are already doing these fantastic things and I#xll be publishing our plans shortly.#xDShoppers queue theof the high street to visit the reopened Sports Direct store in Southampton :KEY EVENTDeath toll from coronavirus hits , after  people die:KEY EVENTBritish embassy confirms Brits can travel to Spain from June  The British embassy in Spain confirmed on Monday that British citizens will be allowed to travel to the Iberian country when it opens its borders next Sunday, but still advised against any non-essential international travel due to the coronavirus.Spain will reopen its borders to most European visitors from June ,  days earlier than previously planned, a Spanish Foreign Ministry said on Sunday.#xCThe Spanish government has confirmed to us that the UK is included within the group of countries to whom these border relaxations will apply,#xD the embassy said via a Twitter account it uses to inform British citizens in Spain, @BritsliveSpain. Nevertheless, it added that the government still advises against all but essential international travel.:Paris restaurants reopen fully post-lockdownParisian restaurants cautiously reopened their indoor dining halls on Monday as the government relaxed one of the last major coronavirus constraints - but with virtually no tourists.President Emmanuel Macron said on Sunday that restaurants and cafes in Paris could reopen fully from Monday, the same day France lted border restrictions for European Union travellers, bringing much needed relief for the hospitality industry.Restaurants outside the Paris region were allowed to open again from June , but in the city where the virus struck hardest venues could only serve customers on outdoor terraces.Restaurants, cafés and bars will have to ensure a minimum one-metre gap between tables and all staff must wear face masks :Lawn Tennis Association launches campaign amid lockdownThe Lawn Tennis Association has launched a major campaign to get more people playing tennis after the coronavirus lockdown by making public facilities more accessible. Tennis was one of the first sports allowed to be played socially across the country following the easing of lockdown measures during the Covid- pandemic. The governing body for the sport in Britain has developed a package of initiatives to support facilities in parks and has targeted , priority locations. The packages include the use of free technology to improve accessibility, including an online booking  and gated access to courts, the development of a park-based competition and interest-free quick access loans for facility improvements. LTA chief executive Scott Lloyd said: #xCPark tennis facilities are absolutely crucial to us achieving increased and sustained participation levels in our sport, and so the development of this work has been a central priority since we launched our new strategy last year and our work to make tennis relevant, accessible, welcoming and enjoyable to anyone. #xCAs park tennis courts open back up following the easing of restrictions from the coronavirus pandemic, the LTA is determined to work in partnership with local authorities to safeguard park tennis venues up and down the country, drive participation in tennis in parks and help open up the sport and its benefits to many more people.#xDThe LTA wants to appeal to more people during lockdown :Pubs and restaurants to open in Northern Ireland next monthPubs, restaurants and hotels are to open in Northern Ireland at the start of July in a major stride out of lockdown. Ministers in the Stormont Executive agreed to the move at a meeting on Monday. From June , caravan parks, camp sites and self-contained tourist accommodation will be able to reopen. A week later, hotels, restaurants, cafes, coffee shops, pubs and bars will be able to welcome customers back. Pubs and bars opening on that date will have to primarilyas restaurants and offer substantial meals. Pubs and restaurants are set to open next month in Northern Ireland :Anecdotal evidence that people are complying with UK quarantineDowning Street said there was #xCanecdotal#xD evidence that people were complying with quarantine measures on arrival in the UK - week after the measures came into force.The Home Office was still considering how to publish official figures on the quarantine regime. The Prime Minister#xs official spokesman said: #xCAs of midnight, no fines have been issued. #xCAnecdotally we are not aware of anyone refusing to provide details when asked to do so.#xDPassengers arrive at Heathrow Terminal  :Small weddings will be allowed soonCommunities Secretary Robert Jenrick has said he hopes to allow small weddings with appropriate social distancing to take place #xCas soon as we can#xD. Tory Laura Farrisasked: #xCCan Mr Jenrick tell the Houseit is possible to say when a date will be announced for summer weddings #xD Responding, Mr Jenrick said: #xCI really appreciate the concerns Ms Farris raises, I know how important weddings are for venues and of course how many people#xs plans have now been disrupted. #xCI can tell her that there is a signicant effort across Government to allow people to hold weddings, in particular small ones with appropriate social distancing, as soon as we can. But this must be done safely.#xD He added that he is working with the Lord Chancellor and faith leaders on the issue. :Nepal to deport foreign tourists for joining coronavirus protest Nepal will deport five foreign tourists and ban them from entering the Himalayan nation for two years after they joined protests against the government#xs response to the coronavirus outbreak, officials said on Monday. Police arrested three Chinese nationals and one each from the United States, Australia and Norway during a street protest on Saturday in the capital Kathmandu. The demonstrators demanded better quarantine facilities, and more testing and transparency in the purchasing of medical supplies to fight COVID-.:PM refuses stars plea to extend free school meals to summer holidaysThe Prime Minister has rejected a call from Manchester United and England star Marcus Rashford to extend the free school meals scheme into the summer holidays. On Monday morning the footballer pleaded with MPs to reconsider their decision not to extend the current food voucher scheme in an open letter #xCwritten from the heart#xD in which he spoke about his own experiences of relying on free school meals.The -year-old Manchester United and England striker urged the authorities to make a U-turn and allow vulnerable children who have been getting free meals during the coronavirus lockdown to continue receiving them in the summer holidays.But today the Prime Minister#xs spokesman confirmed that the scheme would be ending with the school term.He promised to write to the footballer soon after the launch of the maketheuturn campaign urging the government to change their mind.The -year-old Manchester United and England striker urged the authorities to make a U-turn Read the full story here:Homeschooling leads to lockdown anxiety surgeLockdown has seen a surge in anxiety across the UK with married couples the worst affected - largely because of the extra stress of home schooling.Married couples or those in civil partnerships who have reported they are suffering from #xhigh#x levels of anxiety more than doubled in the first month of Britain#xs shutdown.Pensioners aged over  were also twice as likely to be highly stressed as those aged -, the ONS found, with part of the blame being attributed to reporting of their higher risk of serious illness and death from coronavirus, and also their higher levels of loneliness. Both of these groups, married couples and pensioners, reported the lowest anxiety levels pre-pandemic.The figures come after the rules were relaxed allowing #xsupport bubbles#x containing two households, to help those living alone.Parents said the pressures of homeschooling had caused their anxiety to surge Read more on the figures here:Pubs could have just days to prepare for reopeningPubs and restaurants could have just days to prepare to reopen, after Number  was unable to confirm a timetable for relaxing lockdown rules.The roadmap for easing restrictions sets out July  as the earliest date for the hospitality industry to .But Downing Street warned this was conditional on the UK continuing to meet the #xCfive tests#xD for exiting lockdown conditions.Trade bodies have warned pubs would need at least three weeks notice to reopen - and that ran out last weekend.The Prime Minister#xs Official Spokesman said: #xCThe roadmap sets out july  at the earliest for hospitality, and also sets out that that will be conditional on us continuing to meet the five tests.#xCAs with non-essential retail before it we will of course want to give as much notice as we can.#xDRead more here :KEY EVENTUK hospital death toll rises by  in second lowest increase since lockdownThe UK#xs hospital death toll has risen by  in the second lowest increase since the lockdown began. The figures record the coronavirus death toll reported by hospitals, with the full figure include from care homes and the community to be released later today. England reported  new deaths, and Wales recorded four more deaths.While there were no new deaths reported in Scotland, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon stressed the figures were always lower after weekends.Northern Ireland#xs figures are yet to be reported.Click here for the breaking story in full. :Not a single traveller to UK has been fined under coronavirus quarantine rulesNot a single traveller to the UK has been fined for breaking the new -day quarantine rules in their first week, the government revealed today.New arrivals in the UK - including ing Brits - must now isolate for  days after entering the country to stop the spread of coronavirus.Those who refuse to tell Border Force their isolation address can be fined #xA, while those who abscond can be fined #xA,.But critics have claimed the rules could easily be evaded by those wishing to cheat the system.Today it was confirmed that since the policy launched a week ago, not one fine has been issued.Click here to read our full story. :No. insists theres no issue in relations with scientists at daily conferencesNumber  insisted there was not an issue in the Government#xs relations with the scientists who appear at the daily coronavirus press conferences. Askedthere was a problem as there are now fewer appearances by the scientists, the Prime Minister#xs official spokesman said: #xCNo - last week you saw, from memory, the chief medical officer, the chief scientic adviser, you saw NHS England#xs medical director, you saw Baroness Harding who is in charge of test and trace, you also saw the Health and Safety Executive and a couple of others as well... #xCThere won#xt be an expert there every day but you will still see them.#xD It comes after reports that Professor Chris Whitty and Sir Patrick Vallance were on #xCresignation watch#xD. Boris Johnson leaving Downing Street :Nicola Sturgeon plans to absolutely maximise amount of time youngsters spend in schoolNicola Sturgeon has spoken about plans for Scottish youngsters toto schools on August . She said both parents and pupils will be #xCanxious#xD about the impact the coronvirus crisis would have on schooling. There should #xCno doubt about the priority I and the whole Government attaches to making sure our young people do not lose out on education or have their live chances damaged#xD, she said. Ms Sturgeon said ministers expect councils to put in place arrangements that #xCabsolutely maximise#xD the amount of time youngsters spend in school. #xCThe Scottish Government will be scrutinising council plans very closely,#xD she said. #xCAnd where we conclude all possible steps have not been taken to maximise face-to-face teaching and learning we will ask councils to reconsider and revise their plans. #xCWhere there are genuine issues of resources the Scottish Government will work with councils to address those.#xD She added: #xCOur aim will be toto normal schooling as quickly as we possibly can, recognising that along the way we must build the confidence of parents, young people and teachers that schools are safe.:Poundstretcher in talks to close a quarter of UK stores following lockdownPoundstretcher is reportedly in talks to close a quarter of its UK stores, in a restructuring plan that could place thousands of jobs at risk.The chain is this week expected to unveil a new turnaround plan that will determine the fate of its  stores and entire workforce.Under a company voluntary arrangement , up to a quarter of stores could close with rent negotiated at its remaining outlets.Sources at Sky News said that under the CVA,  outlets would see rent paid in full for an initial six-week period, with their survival then reliant on whether they can secure rent cuts.Poundstretcher has been contacted for comment.Click here for our full story. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA traveller claims he was left humiliated at KFC drive-thru when her went for a bargain bucket but was refused service on his horse and cart. Ian Bell says he trotted up to the window expecting to place his order, only to be told he would have to leave for the health and safety of other customers. The -year-old said his beloved steed Jon Jon is good as gold and made the argument, horse and carts were around long before motor cars. Photos show Ian and Jon Jon, a seven-year-old Irish Cob, pitched up outside the KFC restaurant in Carlisle, Cumbria. Ian said: I had queued up behind some cars and was about to order a Bargain Bucket when all of a sudden this manager came out and said aposyouaposre not allowed throughapos. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, click here   I couldnapost believe what I was hearing, Iaposd done nothing wrong. Jon Jon was behaving himself, he was quiet as a lamb - heaposs a very well-behaved horse. In the end I had to go to McDonaldaposs for a Big Mac. No one there batted an eyelid, they didnapost say anything to me at all, they just served me my food. Dad-of-one Ian added: I think my treatment from KFC has been downright disgusting and discriminatory against people who use horse and carts. The horse and cart is a common way to get around where Iaposm from. The fast food franchise has spoken out in defence of the manageraposs decision to deny Ian and Jon Jon service, insisting the safety of guests is really important.  A KFC spokesman said: Hold your horses Carlisle. We’re not looking to stirrup trouble and we’re sorry for Ian and Jon Jon’s experience – but the safety of our guests is really important, so we can’t allow horse drawn vehicles in our drive-thrus.  Ian lives alone in the seaside town of Silloth and Jon Jon resides in a nearby field. The pair often travel  miles to Carlisle by car and horse box, before setting up the carriage and trotting around the streets.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA top marathon runner nicknamed the ‘Iron Lady’ has died after collapsing during a race and not being rescued for  hours. Kateryna Katiushcheva was taking part in a gruelling post-lockdown event in her homeland of Ukraine, when she suffered heat stroke and dehydration and collapsed six miles from the finishing line. There were initial fears that the -year-old runner had been kidnapped before she was finally found in the early hours of Sunday morning in a “grave” condition. Kateryna was rushed to hospital where she died after suffering a massive stroke. The annual Odessa Ultra-Trial Kuyalnik  race is a ’unique’ -mile super marathon contest close to the Black Sea on the River Kuyalnik estuary in the country’s most southerly point. The race is described as “hellish” and “merciless” by one of the organisers. The event was run in intense heat of up to C but at night as Katiushcheva lay unconscious, the temperature plunged. Following the kidnap concerns it has been claimed police were slow to react and search for her. Eventually after eight hours of searches, she was located by police due to her mobile phone signal.  Runner Igor Mishko said: The organisers noticed her disappearance after the finish of the other leaders - and began their own search using a jeep, several cyclists and volunteers. The athlete was a member of Ukraine national team for -hour runs, and last year she won two ultra marathons in Moldova and Kyiv.

A high-level meeting is due to take place between their Portuguese lawyer and detectives involved in the long-running probe. Pressure is mounting on authorities to come clean over what they know about tragic Madeleine’s fate. German prosecutors claim to have evidence she is dead but have so far refused to tell the McCanns what that is. However they have shared the information with Portuguese police, who last night described it as “signicant” and “very important”. Kate and Gerry’s lawyer Rogerio Alves is set to meet with detectives in a matter of days to be given an update on the investigation. He is hoping they will finally reveal what evidence the Germans have against suspect Christian Brueckner. Mr Alves said he will be meeting the Policia Judiciaria this week to find outthey are going to start actively investigating the case again. “I will try to find out what information they have that can support the reopening of the file here,” he said.  “I want to find outthere are new leads for them to chase. I want to know what is being done. “I intend to get answers on these matters this week. “What I hope is that everybody helps to find the truth instead of hiding information, or keeping information for themselves. “We are waiting for more information from the police and from the prosecutor.  “We are waiting for that information that should be provided to us, but there is nothing more we can do but wait. “According to Portuguese law,the prosecutor has new information about the crime he should reopen it. “I don’t know how strong the new evidence is so I don’t know what the prosecutor is going to do. “In terms of the investigation, and the parent’s hopes for justice, last week was a lost week.  “At the moment the police forces are arguing and this row is stupid. It seems they are trying to compete with each other. “Madeleine’s parents don’t want to know which police force thinks it is doing the best. They do not want a war of words. “It is no use – this is a waste of time. “All the police should be doing is trying to solve the case. I want to see full cooperation between the police forces.”  Last week Mr Alves branded German authorities “cruel” for refusing to say what evidence they have that Madeleine was killed. He said Kate and Gerry, of Rothley, Leics, “have a right to know” what happened to their daughter. “They need to know what’s going on,” he said. “It’s a question of legality but also humanity. It’s cruel.” It was claimed yesterday that Brueckner may be flown to Portugal to take part in a reconstruction of the night Madeleine disappeared.  It could prove key to unlocking the case and would be simple to organise once a formal German request is approved by Lisbon. Portuguese legal expert Rui Pereira told Correio da Manha newspaper that any reconstruction depends on countries working together. He said: “A number of procedures could be carried out under the umbrella of international co-operation. “The suspect could be flown to Portugal for the practice of judicial enactments that require him to be present.”

title: pooch looks like completely different
story: NewsPooch looks like completely dferent dog after shedding half his body weightAlicia Taylor and Liam Applegarth, from Watton, Norfolk, were terried when Cocker Spaniel, Bailey, started vomiting blood and rushed him to the vet where he was diagnosed with pancreatitis - a painful inflammation of the organ that can be caused by obesityShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle EditorJamie Blue Mountain:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsEven the vet couldnt believe how much weight Bailey, pictured with owner Liam, had lost on the new diet " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAlicia Taylor, , always wanted the best for her gorgeous Cocker Spaniel, Bailey, taking him for long walks and making sure he ate the correct portions. So she was horried when she found her beloved pooch vomiting blood and rushed him to the vet for tests. Four-year-old Bailey was diagnosed with pancreatitis, a painful inflammation of the organ that can be caused by obesity, and was put on anti-inflammatory medication for two weeks and a diet overhaul was recommended. Alicia, from Watton, Norfolk, said: When youaposre a dog owner you think youaposre doing the very best for your dog. So we really took it to heart when we found out we had contributed to his illness. We felt like weaposd let ourselves down - heaposs our everything. Alicia, , and her boyfriend, Liam Applegarth, , who is in the armed forces, admitted they didnapost know too much about dog nutrition so just bought a bag of food from the supermarket which claimed to be perfect for an all round diet But after his health scare, theyaposve swapped him to a raw food diet and the dference is incredible. She said: I just couldnapost believe how quickly he took to it. It grossed me out at first, the idea of using raw meat, but when you think about it dogs werenapost made to eat kibble.  In the wild theyaposd be eating food theyaposd caught. Between starting his new diet August  and the summer of , Bailey shed half his body weight, slimming down from kg to kg - drawing admiring comments from fellow dog walkers who had known him since he was a puppy. Friends, family and fellow dog walkers were lost for words,said Alicia, who is also delighted to report that he has never suffered with pancreatitis again. The vet was absolutely shocked. He couldnapost believe it, I donapost think he could believe that such dference was made by swapping to raw food  - and heaposs a vet!  And when I started looking at old photos, I realised why everyone was making such a fuss - he really was a super slimming pooch. Alicia and Liam had wanted a dog since they first moved in together, in June , but it had been impossible as they were living in rented accommodation. So, after buying their own place in , getting a puppy had been their priority and they had settled on a Cocker Spaniel, as they thought the breed would suit their personalities and lestyle. Alicia said:  We wanted an active, lively dog to fit in with our lestyle, as weaposre a young couple and quite active - so a Cocker Spaniel ticked all the boxes.  Theyaposre known for their kooky personalities, after all. Falling head over heels for Bailey, who they bought from a local breeder, he made their little family feel complete. Alicia said: He was everything we could have hoped for in a first pet. He was your perfect puppy, so friendly and engaging. He was so happy to see anybody. Wanting to be responsible, they had decided to have him neutered - heeding the warnings that his metabolism might slow, causing him to gain a few kilos, by exercising portion control. Alicia said: We gave him strict portions of a generic, supermarket-bought kibble, as well as daily short walks and a three-hour walk once a week.  So the couple were flummoxed by what was causing his considerable weight gain  - only realising once Alicia started researching alternative diets on the web that it was probably the kind of food they had been giving him. Looking back, we know now it was the kibble that was the weight gain culprit, but we didnapost know anything about nutrition for dogs back then. We just chose the most colourful brand, which made the best claims about dog health. He went from being an energetic, fun-loving dog to a lethargic and lazy hound. Recalling the upsetting day they realised how poorly Bailey was, she said: I woke up one morning and could hear Bailey retching at the bottom of the bed.  Liam was away with the forces at the time. I got up to let Bailey out and he ran into the garden and would not stop throwing up. At first I thought it was just an upset stomach. He didnapost eat anything that day, and the next he was vomiting up blood - it was terrying.  They rushed him to the vet where he was put on a drip for  hours and given a full health screening - including an ultrasound and blood tests. She started researching alternative diets and came across Natures Menu - and hasnapost looked back. She said: He looks like a completely dferent dog.

Rayshard Brooks died in hospital on Friday night after a scuffle with officers outside a Wendyaposs in Georgia, having allegedly failed a sobriety test and resisting arrest after falling asleep in his car. The -year-old was a father to three girls and also had a stepson, WSB-TV reports. Investigators tonight released footage of the struggle with Atlanta Police that preceded him being shot and killed, which comes only weeks after the death of George Floyd in police custody in Minneapolis. It has sparked fresh demonstrations in the streets of Atlanta, which saw the Wendyaposs where Mr Brooks died lit on fire by protesters on Saturday night.to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror email  Images on local television showed the restaurant in flames while an anti-racist march has also completely shut down the Interstate  Highway. Mr Floydaposs death has sparked three weeks of widespread protests against racial discrimination, and in some cases violent clashes with police and right-wing counter-protesters, across the US and around the world.The Georgia Bureau of Investigation has now launched a probe into Mr Brooksapos death. In a statement given to CNN, it says police were called to the restaurant at around .pm on Friday after a man was found to be asleep in his vehicle, blocking the drive-through lane and forcing other customers to drive around him. The GBI says police then gave Mr Brooks a sobriety test, which he failed, leading to the scuffle.  Attorneys L. Chris Stewart and Justin Miller, who are now representing Mr Brooksapos family, released the images on Saturday night. According to broadcaster CBS, he had spent the evening of his death celebrating his eldest daughteraposs birthday. The fatal shooting led to Atlantaaposs police chief, Erika Shields, resigning on Saturday. Shieldsapos statement said: For more than two decades, I have served alongside some of the finest women and men in the Atlanta Police Department. Out of a deep and abiding love for this City and this department, I offered to step aside as police chief. APD has my full support, and Mayor Bottoms has my support on the future direction of this department. I have faith in the Mayor, and it is time for the city to move forward and build trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve. The Atlanta police involved in the shooting have been criticised for the use of firearms, given that Mr Brooks appears to have only had a Taser. The cityaposs mayor, Keisha Lance Bottoms, said: I do not believe that this was a justied use of deadly force and have called for the immediate termination of the officer. US politician Stacey Abrams, a former Georgia political candidate, is among those who have called for restrictions on police use of deadly force.Commenting on Twitter, she said: A Taser is not a deadly weapon. A gun is. Adrenaline and irritation are not the same as mortal fear. Running away should not be punishable by death. Public safety must mean the public is safe. All of us. And Jen Jordan, a Democratic State Senator for Georgiaaposs th District, wrote: Asleep in his car. Thataposs why police were called. Now he is dead after being shot three times in the back as he was running away. #RayshardBrooksshould not be dead. Authorities have not yet released the names of the two officers, who were both white. A video taken from a nearby car, and released by the GBI, shows Mr Brooks on the ground outside his car, struggling with two officers.
