The charity Air Ambulance with HEMS crew on board were also tasked to the incident. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...“Following assessment at the scene, no one was transported to hospital.”Expressing sadness in a post on social media, a spokesperson for the Motocross Club of Northern Ireland said: “The MCCNI committee and club would like to offer our sincere condolences on the passing of one of our club members, Brendan Graham. We were deeply sadden to hear the news.“Many of you will know Brendan from the paddock. He was such a friendly, bubbly, happy young man. He never passed vans without smiling or stopping for a chat. He touched many of our lives.“He gained many friends from coming to the races and we all gained a friend in Brendan. He loved nothing more than a good day’s racing with everyone. He will be greatly missed round the paddock by many. Rest easy Brendan, we will all miss you #.”Brendan was also a talented boxer and a member of the Newtownabbey-based club, Evolution Boxing Club.Paying tribute, a spokesperson for the club said: “Our hearts are broken. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Graham family on the tragic passing of their son, Brendan.“Brendan was a valued member of the club with a passion for sports, who would turn up early and was one of the last to leave. He always enjoyed a joke and had a good bond with everyone in the gym. All the coaches had him marked as a lad who had the potential to do very well.“When he wasn’t boxing he was an aspiring young motocross rider and found the perfect balance between both sports. He would have excelled at either sport and in le. A young man who will be deeply missed by us all.”Mr Graham was a member of the congregation at Victoria Evangelical Hall.A tribute was posted on the church’s Facebook page on Saturday evening. It said: “Unfortunately, today we lost a much-loved member of our church family, Brendan.“To say that we are devastated would be an understatement. Brendan never failed to make us laugh and when he was in church he was always there with a full heart and everyone of us were met with a hug.“Brendan, we will miss you beyond measure. We as a church family can not express the heartbreak we are feeling.“We would ask you to keep Brendan’s family in prayer at this heartbreaking time.”Funeral details were posted on the church’s social media page this morning , stating: “Brendan’s funeral service will be from his home  Copperwood Drive Carrickfergus on Wednesday, June  at .pm. title: new app provide specialist advice gps seconds
story: The Consultant Connect app has been fast-tracked for use in NHS Wales to help deal with the covid- outbreak and support primary care in the long term to offer better advice and guidance to patients.By accessing speedy advice the new app will help prevent unnecessary hospital admissions and referrals and ensure that those needing hospital treatment are managed accordingly.The core service, being rolled out across Wales, gives clinicians access to specialists in respiratory medicine, cardiology, diabetes, palliative care and acute medicine for covid.Health Boards can also add access to a range of local advice that is appropriate to their patientsrsquo needs.A GP or other clinician accesses the service either by dialling a phone number or using the Consultant Connect app.After choosing a speciality from a menu they are connected with a specialist in an average of  seconds.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am very pleased we are able to start rolling out the Consultant Connect in NHS Wales."This will help to support primary care to determine the right treatment for their patients.ldquoRight now it will save crucial time for health care professionals and reduce the amount of hospital visits needed by patients, at a time when our NHS is facing extra pressure.ldquoIn the long-term the use of this technology is an important part of our plan for the future of health one of his articles that such a progressive town as Penarth was without an operatic and dramatic society, writes Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Societypresident, Mary Gardner.The response to his outcry was quickly taken up and within three weeks the Penarth Operatic Society was formed.The Societyrsquos first production was Gilbert  Sullivanrsquos Iolanthe, played at The Hippodrome which later burnt down, and what a glittering opening evening it must have been as the audience wore evening dress.The review featured next day read, ldquoBrilliant Initial Performance.More newsVale council issues warning over the use of parksFines increased for coronavirus lockdown breachesMarie Curie Great Blooming Tea Party goes virtualA few years later in , the drama section came into being and with it a new title of the Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Society, known affectionately as PODS.Since then PODS has progressed down through the decades with many highlights along the way.One being in  when PODS presented that great musical, The King And I, which won the premier prize at the Waterford International Festival, for which the company received a beautul Waterford crystal vase.The Town Council held a reception to honour the Society at the Paget Rooms, and James Callaghan, the local MP, paid his tribute to PODS saying it ldquoadded lustre and brought culture to Penarth.Another landmark was the play, Dear Octopus, by Dodie Smith produced for PODS th anniversary celebrations.One of our most challenging and exciting shows was Cabaret in , which won the National Operatic  Dramatic Associationrsquos award for Best Production and Best Stage Management and Technical presentation.More recently in , to honour and pay tribute to the many men who gave their lives in World War One, PODS presented the very special play, Last Man Standing, which also won a NODA award for Best Drama.In , PODS decided to do pantomime, and this has been a greatly gratying and popular addition to the companyrsquos output.Itrsquos wonderful to see children in the cast having on-stage experience, and then those children in the audience, perhaps for the first time, enjoying and loving live theatre.PODS is a very busy Society putting on four shows a year, a musical, two plays and a pantomime.Mrs Gardner said: ldquoThis year, sadly and very upsettingly after much hard work by all involved, the covid- virus struck as PODS had just set-up at the Paget Rooms ready for its run of Goodnight Mister Tom, only to be told the venue would be shut down next day.ldquoSince January, the Society had also been rehearsing for its May musical, The Full Monty, and that too has had to be cancelled.       ,params: .pushldquoNevertheless, when this terrible emergency is over the company will put on these two productions sometime in the future. ldquoPODS is proud of its achievement in giving much pleasure and entertainment to the local community with its first-class shows over the last  years, and its goal is to make its centenary in  with the help of its faithful audiences, friends and patrons.PODS is always ready to welcome new members, but at the moment it cannot meet or rehearse due to the covid- restrictions.It might be some time before restrictions are lted on groups being able to rehearse together, or audiences allowed back in theatres, meanwhile PODS members keep in touch story: Pictures and videos appeared on social media on Monday of groups of people sitting on the benches along the seafront, and groups of people gathering along the front.Currently, lockdown measures the regulations.ldquoWe only apply [a Fixed Penalty Notice] as a last resort.ldquoItrsquos a matter for the inidual to ensure they follow the regulations.Some Penarth residents said they were concerned by the number of people along the seafront on Monday.Melanie Regan, , said she didnrsquot feel safe to walk along the seafront with her husband due to the number of people there.ldquoIt is so busy out there we donrsquot even walk out there, she said. ldquoThe bank holiday was packed, but it is not just the bank holidays.ldquoWith the amount of traffic and cars parked, itrsquos not just local people either.ldquoWe donrsquot feel safe going out there.Michelle Crow, from Penarth, said: ldquoWhile I was on my daily exercise walk with my dogs it felt like Windsor Road into Penarth was quite busy considering we are supposed to be in lockdown.However, other residents said the number of people at the seafront was not more than expected and everyone was following the guidance.Mary Taylor, from Penarth, said: ldquoWe were having our exercise along the promenade on Sunday.ldquoYes, most seats were occupied, there were people stood in between but on the whole they were s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE RNLI in Wales has reacted to the Welsh Governmentrsquos plans for easing lockdown with an important safety warning.The Governmentrsquos changes, from Monday, June , will limit people to staying local and not generally travel more than five miles to reduce the risk of the coronavirus spreading.People from two dferent households in the same local area will be permitted to meet up as long as they are outdoors, and they maintain strict social distancing.The lesaving charity has called for the public to stay safe.RNLI lesaving manager, Matt Crofts said: ldquoAfter a warm spring coupled with the easing of a lockdown which has seen many of us unable to visit our local beaches, we expect many people to be eager to hit the coast.ldquoThe changes to Government guidance does not mean our coasts are safe.ldquoThe dangers that have always been there remain.ldquoWe ask those who are local to beaches to continue to be aware of the inherent dangers.ldquoOur strong advice to the Welsh public, who are not local to a beach, is to follow the Welsh Government guidance to meet outdoors and exercise locally and not to travel to the coast.ldquoAir temperatures may be warming up but the sea temperature remains consistently chilly all year, jumping or falling into cold water or spending longer periods than normal submerged in the water can lead to, potentially fatal, cold water shock.Water safety lead for the RNLI in Wales, Chris Cousens urged people to remember the safety advice.He said: ldquoStay in familiar surroundings and follow the Welsh Government advice.ldquoDo not put yourself, your family and emergency services at risk by taking risks or assuming it lsquowonrsquot happen to yoursquo.ldquoIf you do see someone at risk call  and ask for the coastguard.A high proportion of calls for the RNLI in Wales are to those who have been to people cut off by the tide, including during the lockdown period.Some parts of Wales have among the highest tidal range in Europe.A beach that was clear yesterday at pm might be completely covered in sea at the same time today.Mr Cousens said: ldquoIf you are heading out for a coastal walk, make sure it is safe before you go.ldquoAlways check the tide times and conditions before you set off and while out, be aware of your surroundings and keep an eye on the tide direction.ldquoAsk for local advice and look out for safety signs.ldquoAlways carry a means of calling for help and know to call  and ask for the coastguardyou or someone  is at risk.The RNLI is working to start a leguard service on several beaches in Wales and is in discussion with the Welsh Government, local authorities, landowners, and other partners.At present there are no RNLI leguards on beaches in Wales. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey from Monday, June .People who have been shielding can now take exercise outdoors and meet people from another household, as long as it takes place outdoors.There are two changes to the advice for this group.Outdoor exercise is unlimited, as long as iniduals strictly follow social distancing rules and hygiene practices.Those who are shielding can meet outside with people from another household ndash but should not go into another personrsquos house or share food with them.Welsh Government minister for health and social services, Vaughan Gething announced the changes on Sunday, May .There are no other changes being made to the advice for those who are shielding at this stage.People who are shielding should continue to follow all the other advice previously given.They should not go shopping or attend work outside of home.They should continue to have food and medicine delivered to them.This advice comes from chief medical officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton.He said: ldquoRisk can never be completely eliminated but we advise those shielding to exercise at times that are less busy, so the risk of contact with others is reduced.ldquoWe have advised everyone in Wales to maintain social distance of two metres and keep good hygiene when meeting outdoors."For those who are shielding, strictly following these rules is vital.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am pleased that so many have been shielding so diligently ndash not only protecting themselves but also helping to protect our NHS.ldquoWe recognise how challenging these last few months, with minimal face-to-face contact with others, has been.ldquoI am incredibly proud of all those who have and continue to provide the vital support to enable people to shield.ldquoOur local authority partners, pharmacies, volunteers, and major food retailers have all pulled together to make shielding possible.The chief medical officer is continuing to develop his advice for shielding people after June .All who are shielding will receive a letter from Dr Atherton in the coming fortnight setting out the next steps. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: contact tracing system wales rolled out
story: From today, anyone who has a positive coronavirus test result will be contacted by a team of contact tracers and asked for details of everyone they have had close contact with while they have had symptoms.Close contact means anyone who has been within m of and had a face-to-face-conversation, had skin-to-skin contact with or have coughed on, or been in other forms of contact with for a minute or longer.It also means they have been within m of for more than  minutes or they have travelled in a vehicle with or sat near on public transport.All these close contacts will be followed up and will be asked to self-isolate for  days as a precaution to prevent the virus spreading further.From Monday, June  contact tracing will be supported by a new online system, which will give people the option to provide details of their close contacts electronically.Mr Gething said: ldquoTodayrsquos roll-out of the contact tracing element of our Test, Trace, Protect strategy is a signicant step forward in the gradual move out of lockdown.ldquoOver the last few months, thanks to the help of the public and the way they have followed the stay-at-home rules, we have managed to slow the spread of the virus to the point where we can today ease the regulations to enable family and friends to meet again.ldquoContact tracing is a tried and tested method of bringing outbreaks of infectious diseases under control and we hope it will do the same with coronavirus ndash but for it to be successful, we need everyonersquos help and cooperation in sharing details about their movements and contacts."We also need people to self-isolatethey may be at risk.ldquoThe scientic advice is clear ndash we need a contact tracing system in place before we begin to lt restrictions further.Health boards and local authorities are working together to deliver contact tracing.The system has been trialled in four health board areas over the last two weeks and more than  contact tracers have so far been employed.This number is likely to rise as the system is rolled out.Testing capacity has been increased to support contact tracing and home tests and tests at the drive-through centres for both critical workers and the public can be booked online.Full details of the contact tracing system are available at gov.wales testing-coronavirus article_url   content_id   site_id title: meet environment author stephen moss penarth bookstore online event
story: Mr Moss will talk to bookshop owner Mel Grfin about his new book, The Accidental Countryside, before taking questions from the virtual audience.This online event will take place at pm on Wednesday, June  via Zoom conference call.More storiesPopular book club moves online to adapt to isolationGrfin Books nominated for Best Independent Bookshop AwardIndependent bookshop to host crime author Matt JohnsonWhat links Britainrsquos Iron Age hill forts and urban skyscrapers Churchyards and docklands Golf courses and gravel pits Together, they make up The Accidental Countryside.Wherever you go in Britain ndash in the city, town, or countryside ndash you come across hidden havens for wildle.They may be home to sand lizards and stoats, adders and orchids, water voles and peregrine falcons.In The Accidental Countryside, Mr Moss tells the fascinating and uplting story of how wildle has taken advantage of us ndash often when we least expected it.He also asks a crucial question: without these places, will Britainrsquos wildle be able to survive Mr Moss is a lelong naturalist, broadcaster and author.His books include The Twelve Birds of Christmas, Wild Kingdom: Bringing Back Britainrsquos Wildle and The Wren: A Biography. title: schools wales urged open august holidays
story: An announcement on the re-opening of schools is expected this week, having been closed to the vast majority of pupils since March , with local authorities being told that at least three weeks notice will be provided,But despite the scheduled summer holidays set to start in mid July, leaving only approximately three weeks of lessons at most,the National Education UnionCymru claims that plans for the six week break to be brought forward a month had been abandoned.More NewsDeaths in Vale of Glamorgan jump  per cent higher in AprilBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandMeet environment author Stephen Moss at Penarth bookstore online eventUnion secretaryDavid Evans, in a Facebook post, said that such a move would result in a -week term in the autumn with just a one-week break in the middle for the teachers, adding that thiswould mean breaking summer arrangements and resulting ldquocontractual issues, describing such plans as a ldquonon-starter.But Arfon MS Sian Gwenllian says thatbringing this yearrsquos summer holidays forward should continue to be ldquofully explored, suggesting a phased and gradual re-opening of schools in August rather than September, but onlyit was safe to do so.Plaid Cymrursquos education spokesperson claims there could beldquoeducational advantages in bringing forward the start of the autumn term.This, she added, could further pave the way for permanent changesand a re-configuring of the traditionalthree term year in a way that would be ldquoless disjointed andmore in tune with modern-day needs.ldquoThe educational advantages of bringing this yearrsquos summer holidays forward and beginning the autumn term in August should continue to be fully explored, she said.ldquoBefore the Coronavirus crisis there were on-going discussions about school term s and the need to change from three to four school terms and making the summer holidays shorter.ldquoWith need to re-visit those discussions in the wake of Coronavirus and now may be the time to consider changing school terms permanently and toreconfigurethe annual school pattern.She added that the current practice ofldquointense half terms followed by a short holiday has caused both teachers and pupils to become tired, claiming that many teacherssay that the summer term is ldquotoo long ndash especiallyfor children who are not supported with their learning at home.She concluded,ldquoAt the moment in Wales, terms are of dferent swith holidays coming irregularlyand yet research shows that continuity and title: check catch prepare summer september   wales schools enter next phase
story: Education minister Kirsty Williams MS says all schools will start the next phase on Monday, June , with the term extended by a week, therefore ending on Monday, July .In the next academic year, beginning in September, the intention is that the autumn half-term break will be expanded to two weeks.In each school there will be a phased approach.More storiesWelsh Government education minister Kirsty Williams sets out thinking on schools Welsh Government provides schools with new mental health supportSchools in Wales will remain closed on June , announces education minister Kirsty WilliamsYear groups will be split into cohorts with staggered starts, lessons, and breaks.This will mean, at most, a third of pupils present at any one time, though schools may need time to reach this level of operation.There will be much smaller classes, providing secure dedicated time with teachers and classmates.This time will include online and personalised classroom experience, getting children and teachers ready for a similar experience in September.Next week, the Welsh Government will publish guidance to support schools, as well as further and higher education institutions.This will include information on managing their facilities and logistical arrangements, including buildings, resources, cleaning and transport.The Government is also publishing a paper from its covid- Technical Advisory Group, representing the latest understanding of the virus with respect to children and education.Further Education colleges are ensuring that appropriate measures are being taken to re-open for face-to-face learning from Monday, June .They will prioritise those students requiring licence to practice assessments and vulnerable learners.This follows close working with government and the joint trade unions.Guidance for childcare providers will also be published in the next week, supporting them to increase the numbers of children in attendance alongside schools.Ms Williams said her announcement gave schools three and a half weeks to continue preparing for the next phase.She said: ldquoWe will use the last weeks of the summer term to make sure pupils, staff and parents are prepared ndash mentally, emotionally and practically ndash for the new normal in September.ldquo June means there will have been one full month of test, trace and protect, which will continue to expand.ldquoI can also announce that teachers will be a priority group in our new antibody-testing programme.ldquoAs we continue to keep Wales safe, this approach will be critical.ldquoThe evolving science suggests that warm weather and sunlight gives us the best opportunity to ensure more time in school.       ,params: .pushldquoWaiting until September would mean almost half a year without schooling.ldquoThat would be to the detriment to the wellbeing, learning progress and mental health of our young people.ldquoThis is and has been a worrying period for us all.ldquoI know that many will feel apprehensive.ldquoWe have not rushed this work and this decision.ldquoThe three-and-a-half-week period before the next phase also gives us time to keep watch on developments where and provides further check-points to review evidence and the roll-out of testing.ldquoThis is the best practical option that meets my five principles which underpin my decision making.ldquoI am also convinced that it is only by ing to their own school that we will see increased attendance from our more vulnerable and disadvantaged children.ldquoWorking together we will secure equity and excellence for pupils as they check in, catch up, and prepare for summer and September. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE McDonalds drive thru in Barry has re-openedfollowing its closure due to the coronavirus pandemic in March this year.The drive thru in the Ty Verlon estate-based store is located near the roundabout which provides access to and from Wenvoe, Cardf, Dinas Powys, Sully, and Penarth.Other drive thrus to re-open include the Cardf stores at Culverhouse Cross, Excelsior Road, Cardf Bay, Longwood Drive, and Newport Road.Extensive queues formed when two drive thru reopened in Pencoed, Bridgend, on Tuesday, June .A McDonaldrsquos spokeswoman said: "This is only possible following the hard work of the teams in our  pilot restaurants."Our employees, franchisees and suppliers have worked tirelessly to implement new procedures to enable safe working so that we can now help all parts of the UK and Ireland to enjoy theof the Big Mac."With fewer employees working in our kitchens and service areas, our teams will still need your patience and support as they continue to adjust to the new ways of working."Face coverings, gloves, perspex screens and new safety and hygiene processes mean it will look dferent, it will take a little longer and as we have seen in the pilot restaurants, we expect demand will be high."Please bear with us, we will continue to put our people first ndash their safety is our priority."She added: "In the last week, on occasion, we have taken the decision to close drive thru lanes where demand has impacted local communities or the safety of our people or customers.""We will continue to work with local authorities and the police as we extend our reopening plans."With smaller teams, we will still be offering a limited menu over reduced hours, and we ask that you make contactless payments and limit your spend to pound."We are continuing to review these measures as we reopen, but for now, these restrictions remain in place to help our employees, customers and delivery partner couriers to remain safe.The Barry McDonalds drive thru is scheduled to reopen at am. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url title: shielding continue   people wales
story: Shielding continues for all generations" Shielding to continue for , people in WalesA general view of a close up of the hands of an elderly woman at home.." Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentALMOST , people will this week start receiving a letter from the chief medical Officer for Wales setting out the latest advice to protect them from coronavirus.They will be asked to continue shielding until Sunday, August , but the letter will also describe how the medical advice has changed to enable them to go outdoors to meet other people for the first time since the start of the pandemic.The shielded group are people who are classed as extremely vulnerable to developing serious illnessthey contract coronavirus because they have a specic health condition.They have been following strict shielding advice for  weeks.MORE STORIES"Check in, Catch up, Prepare for summer and September" - Wales schools to enter next phaseContact tracing system for Wales rolled-outWelsh Government lockdown message changed to Stay Local to Keep Wales SafeWalesrsquo chief medical officer, Dr Frank Atherton, said: ldquoSince the start of the pandemic, we have been focused on ensuring people who are at greatest risk are protected from coronavirus.ldquoThe spread of coronavirus is being carefully monitored ndashit gets lower, it is possible those within the shielded group will be able to do more.ldquoIf it gets higher, we may advise those people to stop going outside and to stay at home again.Earlier this week, the Welsh Government announced a change in advice for people who are shielding, based on a review of the evidence by the four UK chief medical officers.From June , everyone who is shielding are being advised they can leave their homes to meet people from another household outdoors, as long as strictly follow to social distancing rules and good hygiene measures. This includes exercising outdoors.The new August shielding date does not affect this updated advice.Dr Atherton said: ldquoWe are asking all those in the shielding group to continue to shield until August  because coronavirus has not gone away.ldquoWe want to do all we can to keep those people in this group safe and that means asking them to continue to shield.ldquoI will continue to work with my chief medical officer colleagues to review the evidence for this group and will write to them again in the summer.Everyone in the shielding group has been asked to continue to rely on their existing support networks ndash including family and friends ndashfor help with everyday tasks, such as food shopping and collecting prescription medicines.For those who do not have anyone locally, the Welsh Government has worked with local authorities and the Wales Council for Voluntary Action , major food retailers, GPs and pharmacies to ensure they can access the support they need to continue shielding.The arrangements for weekly food boxes for those people who are shielding who have no support from family or friends will continue to be in place.The Welsh Government also continues to work with supermarket retailers in Wales which offer online shopping and home delivery to make sure priority slots are available for people who are shielding.Dr Atherton added: ldquoA huge amount of work has been going on to support people who are shielding and Irsquod particularly like to thank local authorities, the WLGA, WCVA and county voluntary councils for their ongoing work and support. title: penarth church blown away response virtual sunday services
story: Members of the Tabernacle Baptist Churchhave been live streaming their brilliant virtual Sunday services via Facebook Live and Youtube, and the services have attracted hundreds of viewers, with some as far as Germany tuning in.More NewsBarry McDonalds drive thru is back in businessPupils in Wales canto school on June , Welsh Government announceBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandStarting on the second week of lockdown at the end of March, the videos have grown in popularity, and church member Jack Westmore says it is ldquosomething good to come out of a tough time.ldquoIt has been a way of bringing some familiar faces to peoplersquos homes every week, and is something for our members to look forward to, said Mr Westmore. ldquoSome are also not members and are generally interested and want to have a Sunday service.ldquoWe are very lucky that we have some brilliant musicians and tech-savvy members who have really stood up to the plate and made this lockdown bearable for so many of us.Church Elder Claire Grafton explained the impact of the virtual services, adding: ldquoWe have two elderly members who tune in, and one isnrsquot as good with the technology as the other, but one holds the screen right up to the other and they sing along. Itrsquos wonderful to see.The services have been so successful that the congregation is considering continuing its virtual services when lockdown is lted.ldquoBefore lockdown we were getting  visitors regularly on a Sunday, so I would assume that can no longer happen, so the virtual services are certainly something we are considering for the long term, said Ms Grafton.ldquoBut we canrsquot wait until we are back to the church and we are putting plans in place to ensure we can do that as soon as possible.To see Tabs Penarths videos, visit their Facebook page at https:www.facebook TabsPenarth  or their Youtube channel at https:www.youtube channel UCMwHmBLFoZkTPgNHZEw. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: world environment day wales can lead charge quest truly green recovery
story: As the world marks World Environment Day , Sir David has underlined NRWrsquos commitment to supporting the Welsh Government to deliver a green recovery that prioritises sustainable economic growth and benefits the climate and our natural environment.He also outlined how Wales must lead the way on a green route out of the covid- crisis and how Walesrsquo response to the lockdown will play a critical role in determining our effectiveness - or otherwise - in responding to the climate and nature emergencies.MORE STORIESPorthkerry Park pond project improves Barry environmentCadoxton Brook flood scheme plans will go on display at Dinas Powys Community LibraryCoastal areas expected to be hit by large wavesSir David said: ldquoThe impact of covid- has brought sharply into focus the importance we place on our local environment ndash particularly when our access to it has been limited to serve a greater purpose.ldquoIt has also made the case for tackling the climate emergency starker than ever before.The pledges NRW made last year to respond to that challenge remain at the heart of everything we do.The concept of a sustainable recovery will only add momentum to our approach to tackling the climate emergency, and deeper instil the commitment needed to succeed.Looking at how a green recovery could effectively be achieved, NRW suggests that an overall package could focus on a recovery that strengthens our local economies by capitalising on the renewed sense of place and connection we now have with our communities and developing active travel measures which will help to safeguard the quality of the air we breathe.NRW also suggests developing support packages for businesses and sectors that have decarbonisation and nature-based solutions at their core and reforming and developing longer-term policy ambitions in areas such as post-Brexit agricultural and land management support, and the approach to developing a more circular economy.Sir David also reiterated the importance of approaching the green recovery as a coalition with one voice.He added: ldquoThis World Environment Day we need everyone in Wales ndash the government, the private, third and tourism sectors, environmental NGOs, the agricultural and recreational sectors and our communities across Wales - to work together to confront this global challenge head on and seize the opportunity to lead the charge for a truly green recovery. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new app crucial sorting bookings vale glamorgan recycling centre
story: First Minister Mark Drakeford announced last month that recycling centres could reopen as part of the easing of coronavirus restrictions.More than , bookings were made on the first day when they reopened in the Vale of Glamorgan ndash  bookings were made every minute.The Zipporah app called Generic, is helping people in the county to book an appointment. This is proving vital in helping recycling centres manage attendance, maintain physical distancing and reduce queuing.MORE STORIESNew app to provide specialist advice to GPs in secondsNew pound, fund to help digital firms develop technology to combat coronavirusSouth Wales freemasons donate  tablets to hospitalsResidents are also provided with clear instructions and procedures to follow before arriving and during their visit to a recycling centre.The app has also been taken up by local authorities outside Wales. Zipporah is providing it to all free of charge.Economy, Transport and North Wales Minister, Ken Skates said:ldquoThis is a fantastic example of a Welsh company taking action in a time of crisis to introduce a new product for the benefit of public services and local residents.ldquoIndications show the Generic app has already proved a success at recycling centres in the Vale of Glamorgan. This is absolutely essential in ensuring physical distancing rules are maintained and people can come and go with confidence and ease.ldquoIrsquod like to thank Zipporah and the Vale of Glamorgan Council for working collaboratively to bring a successful solution into the public domain.Zipporahrsquos technical director Scott Burton said:"Our appointment solution has already been incredibly effective especially in facilitating the organised re-opening of recycling centres ndash not only in Wales but also across England and Scotland.ldquoAs well as keeping recycling centres running smoothly, Zipporah technology has been crucial in allowing social distancing to be maintained ndash upholding the safety of both the public and staff alike.ldquoWersquore delighted with how successful the system has been in benefiting those using during this challenging period.Deputy Minister for Housing and Local Government, Hannah Blythyn said:ldquoWe have had to adapt our ways of working, since the coronavirus outbreak and it is fantastic to see local authorities and businesses coming together and using innovative technology to ensure key public services are maintained.ldquoEnsuring the safety of staff and the public at recycling centres is vital.The Generic app has not only helped to achieve this but has allowed recycling centres to run smoothly while adopting social distancing. I hope wersquoll see more of this collaborative working in the future as we respond to the pandemic.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Peter King said: ldquoWersquore delighted with how smoothly our household waste recycling centres have been able to reopen after a period of closure.ldquoAs anticipated demand for these facilities was extremely high, but thanks to proper planning and the hard work of council staff many potential problems relating to queuing and waiting times have been avoided.ldquoThe implementation of a booking system was crucial to the reopening operation and wersquod like to thank Zipporah for their support.ldquoTheyrsquove provided us with reliable and robust software that has stood up well to signicant pressure.Vale resident, Stuart Evans said: ldquoAfter a couple of months of having a full garden of shelving units, carpet, underlay, I was so grateful to be able to get to the recycling centre in Barry.ldquoTime slots worked perfectly and it felt so lsquonormalrsquo.ldquoStaff were very organised and helpful. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: wales make face masks compulsory public transport
story: Mark Drakeford said Englands decision to bring in a requirement for coverings had raised issues for people commuting between the two countries.It came as Public Health Wales said a further four people had died after testing positive for coronavirus, taking the total number of deaths to ,, while the number of positive cases grew by  to ,.More NewsLuxury car manufacturer Aston Martin to axe  jobsMans efforts toWorld War One Penarth soldiers plaque found in New ZealandPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideOn Friday, Mr Drakeford was questioned about his governments position on non-medical coverings after a trade union representing doctors in Wales said bringing in rules would help control the spread of Covid- and save lives.Mr Drakeford told the Governments daily press briefing in Cardf: "The context for face coverings has changed because of an announcement made yesterday in England about mandatory use of face masks on public transport."That will not come in until June , and that gives us a short number of days in order to consider the position here in Wales recognising that changed context."Mr Drakeford said a "definitive statement" on the issue would be made in the first part of next week, and that detailed questions about Englands new rules would be explored with ministers and officials in Westminster.But he said the UK Government had not discussed or given advanced notice of the decision with Wales, and questioned whether England was concerned with "making the headline, and then worrying about the detail afterwards"."I wish that wed had a chance to explore this with the UK Government before they made the announcements," he said."That would have allowed us to have some answers to the questions that I raised today before the event rather than after the event."But while on the bulk of issues we continue to be able to have discussion and co-operation in advance of decision making, in a small number of cases we hear about it only after the decision has been made."He added: "Were going to have to use the time we now have to find out from them the extent to which they have got answers to these questions in advance of making the decision, or whether its a matter of making the headline, and then worrying about the detail afterwards."Mr Drakeford said the advice from the chief medical officer for Wales remained that wearing face masks gave people "some marginal extra protection" but was not sufficient to make it mandatory."The chief medical officer has expressed his anxieties that people might do more risky things because they think a face mask offers them protection, which it doesnt," Mr Drakeford said."But context changes because in England it is mandatory to use face masks while on public transport."Trains and roads between north and south Wales weave in and out of the border all the time and in a sheer practical sense, we have to think through whether having separate regimes is a possibility when you can leave on a train that starts in Wales, goes into England, comes back into Wales, goes back into England, comes back into Wales."Earlier on Friday the British Medical AssociationWales called on the Welsh Government to change its stance on non-medical face coverings, and ensure a supply are available to the public.The trade unions council chair for Wales, Dr David Bailey, said: "BMA Cymru Wales advocates the wearing of face coverings by the public in areas where they cannot socially distance."There still remains a considerable risk of infection, and emerging evidence has shown thatmouths and noses are covered when people are in areas where they cannot socially distance, it may help in controlling the spread of infection of Covid- and therefore save lives."BMA Cymru Wales is calling on the Welsh Government to change their position immediately, to lessen the risk of the public spreading the virus."Wales main train operator, Transport for Wales, said it would "work collaboratively" with partners to ensure passengers were kept safe travelling across borders.A spokesman said: "The cross-border nature of our network means that we will continue to work collaboratively with industry partners to ensure customers understand how they can travel safely as they travel between Wales and England."The safety of our colleagues and customers is our top story: Mark Drakeford said Englands decision to bring in a requirement for coverings had raised issues for people commuting between the two countries.It came as Public Health Wales said a further four people had died after testing positive for coronavirus, taking the total number of deaths to ,, while the number of positive cases grew by  to ,.More NewsLuxury car manufacturer Aston Martin to axe  jobsMans efforts toWorld War One Penarth soldiers plaque found in New ZealandPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideOn Friday, Mr Drakeford was questioned about his governments position on non-medical coverings after a trade union representing doctors in Wales said bringing in rules would help control the spread of Covid- and save lives.Mr Drakeford told the Governments daily press briefing in Cardf: "The context for face coverings has changed because of an announcement made yesterday in England about mandatory use of face masks on public transport."That will not come in until June , and that gives us a short number of days in order to consider the position here in Wales recognising that changed context."Mr Drakeford said a "definitive statement" on the issue would be made in the first part of next week, and that detailed questions about Englands new rules would be explored with ministers and officials in Westminster.But he said the UK Government had not discussed or given advanced notice of the decision with Wales, and questioned whether England was concerned with "making the headline, and then worrying about the detail afterwards"."I wish that wed had a chance to explore this with the UK Government before they made the announcements," he said."That would have allowed us to have some answers to the questions that I raised today before the event rather than after the event."But while on the bulk of issues we continue to be able to have discussion and co-operation in advance of decision making, in a small number of cases we hear about it only after the decision has been made."He added: "Were going to have to use the time we now have to find out from them the extent to which they have got answers to these questions in advance of making the decision, or whether its a matter of making the headline, and then worrying about the detail afterwards."Mr Drakeford said the advice from the chief medical officer for Wales remained that wearing face masks gave people "some marginal extra protection" but was not sufficient to make it mandatory."The chief medical officer has expressed his anxieties that people might do more risky things because they think a face mask offers them protection, which it doesnt," Mr Drakeford said."But context changes because in England it is mandatory to use face masks while on public transport."Trains and roads between north and south Wales weave in and out of the border all the time and in a sheer practical sense, we have to think through whether having separate regimes is a possibility when you can leave on a train that starts in Wales, goes into England, comes back into Wales, goes back into England, comes back into Wales."Earlier on Friday the British Medical AssociationWales called on the Welsh Government to change its stance on non-medical face coverings, and ensure a supply are available to the public.The trade unions council chair for Wales, Dr David Bailey, said: "BMA Cymru Wales advocates the wearing of face coverings by the public in areas where they cannot socially distance."There still remains a considerable risk of infection, and emerging evidence has shown thatmouths and noses are covered when people are in areas where they cannot socially distance, it may help in controlling the spread of infection of Covid- and therefore save lives."BMA Cymru Wales is calling on the Welsh Government to change their position immediately, to lessen the risk of the public spreading the virus."Wales main train operator, Transport for Wales, said it would "work collaboratively" with partners to ensure passengers were kept safe travelling across borders.A spokesman said: "The cross-border nature of our network means that we will continue to work collaboratively with industry partners to ensure customers understand how they can travel safely as they travel between Wales and England."The safety of our colleagues and customers is our top priority and wed like to reinforce the message to stay local and only use public transportthe journey is essential and theres no other travel alternative." article_url   content_id   site_id title: south wales detectorists discover treasure nine occasions
story: The British Museum said it was pleasing to see local museums across the country acquiring these "important archaeological objects", but urged treasure hunters to follow the laws surrounding metal detecting.More NewsNew app crucial in sorting bookings at Vale of Glamorgan recycling centreLuxury car manufacturer Aston Martin to axe  jobsPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideIn , there were nine treasure finds reported to Central South Wales Coroners Court, which is responsible for holding treasure inquests.It means a total of  discoveries in the last three years in the area.Across England and Wales, , finds were reported last year ndash  per cent more than the year before.Lincolnshire was the best area for treasure, with  finds last year alone. In contrast, no treasure whatsoever was found in  areas.The Treasure Act, introduced in , defines treasure as discoveries older than  years.These include coins, prehistoric metallic objects and artefacts that are at least  per cent precious metal such as gold or silver.All potential treasure finds are processed by the British Museum, whose experts advise coroners on whether the find fits the definition of treasure.If a coroner rules that it is treasure, both local and national museums are given the chance to acquire the pieces, and the finder will be paid a sum depending on the treasures value.Butthe find is determined not to be treasure, or no museums want it, then it is ed to the treasure hunter.A Ministry of Justice report on last years treasure finds said the number of discoveries has been steadily increasing since the Treasure Act commenced ndash rising from just  finds in .There were  inquests concluded last year, with more than  per cent ing a verdict of treasure.Ian Richardson, treasure registrar at the British Museum, said: "The purpose of the Treasure Act is to enable important archaeological objects to be acquired by museums, for the benefit of all."It is pleasing to see local museums interested in acquiring a number of these findsthey are declared Treasure."Anyone fortunate enough to discover something they think is treasure must report their finding to the coroner within two weeks, so the court can hold an inquest to decide who should get the to keep it.Failure to do so can result in an unlimited fine or up to three months in prison.With metal detecting being permitted again as lockdown lts, Mr Richardson urged people to continue to follow the Code of Practice for Responsible Metal Detecting and report their discoveries, including Treasure. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA CAMPAIGN to save the ancient woodland of Cwm George and Casehill Woods near Dinas Powys, has resulted in success.National Resources Waleshad proposed constructing a dam m wide and .m high in the meadow at the Woodland Trust site in Dinas Powys.NRW proposed the dam as one option to alleviate potential flood risk.More NewsVale nurse developed coronavirus symptoms after sitting with patient, inquest toldMillions become unpaid carers due to coronavirus crisisPenarth RNLI station marks  years despite current coronavirus lockdownThe campaign by the Save Dinas Powys Woods and Protect Homes from Flooding group was launched in March  after the Woodland Trust said NRW was proposing to build a dam within its site of Cwm George and Casehill Woods.The group said the proposals would involve cutting down  square metres of trees including  square metres of ancient trees and regular flooding upstream during high rainfall would result in further destruction of ancient trees, hedgerows, wildle, and plants.Dormice and other protected species like bats were at risk, the group said.The woods, much-loved by the community, attracts visitors from other areas and is the Woodland Trustrsquos most visited site in Wales with more than , visitors.Hundreds of people took part in marches in  to oppose the dam.NRW released its draft Outline Business Case in February  and a consultation period with the local community took place.Hundreds of people attended a meeting in February to oppose the dam and they wrote to NRW, with their views, during the coronavirus lockdown.Chairman of Save Dinas Powys Woods  Protect Homes From Flooding, Peter Smith said the group welcomed the announcement that NRW will not develop a dam in the Dinas Powys Woods.ldquoLocal people recognise the flood risk in the village, but are overwhelmingly in favour of a natural flood management programmein the Cadoxton River and Eastbrook catchments, plus improved channel maintenance andrequired local hard defences, rather than an environmentally unfriendly dam, Dr Smith said.ldquoOur proposals will slow the flow of the rivers upstream thus reducing the risk of flash flooding, and by removing obstacles improve flow downstream.ldquoWe now look forward to working with NRW and The Woodland Trust to design an effective NFM scheme.ldquoBoth have expertise in this area, and, having made funds available for NFM projects, we know that the Welsh Government is keen for Wales to become an exemplar of good practice. community involvement and support will remain key features of our campaign.He added: ldquoWe are grateful to people far and wide who have supported our campaign, including the Woodland Trust, our local community councils, and county councillors.ldquoWe extend our particular thanks our local MS, Jane Hutt, for her advocacy and support.Community councillor, Chris Franks said NRW must not now ignore any problems.ldquoClearly over the years there has been reduced spending on maintenance of the stream through Dinas Powys and towards Barry, he said.ldquoThe public has said that the NRW must improve monitoring of flows on the Cadoxton River, implement natural flood management measures and improve flow at Cardf Road bridge where the stream passes under the A to reduce flood risk.Vale MS Jane Hutt said: ldquolsquoFollowing our meeting on May  Sir David Henshaw chairman of NRW wrote to me on May  to say that NRW received almost  responses to our consultation on the Outline Business Case with the vast majority being opposed to the upstream storage option on the Cadoxton Brook.NRW chairman, Sir Henshaw said: ldquoWhen we consider the marginal case for this option, it is therefore clear that we will not be pursuing an upstream storage scheme. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey Organisationand recommending people in Wales wear three-layer face coverings in situations where social distancing is not possible.The evidence remains clear that maintaining a two-metre distance and good hand hygiene is the most effective way to protect yourself and others from contracting coronavirus.But updated guidance from the WHO said three layer face coverings could help provide some control of the virus in specic circumstances.This updated advice only applies to people who are not showing symptoms of coronavirus.People who are symptomatic must self-isolate for seven days and get a test, as set out in existing guidance.Unless the test shows a negative result, they must not go out during this time, even with a face covering or mask.MORE STORIESWelsh Government lockdown message changed to Stay Local to Keep Wales SafeContact tracing system for Wales rolled outShielding to continue for , people in WalesHealth minister, Vaughan Gething said: ldquoWashing your hands, avoiding touching your face and maintaining a two-metre distance from others remain the best way of stopping the spread of the virus.ldquoOn Friday , the WHO updated their guidance on face coverings, advising that they should be considered in settings where maintaining social distancing is dficult."However, to be crystal clear, wearing a face covering does not replace the need for social distancing or washing your hands regularly.ldquoFurther scientic evidence is needed on the benefits to the wider public of wearing face coverings, but observational findings so far suggest that homemade or purchased three-layer face-coverings might reduce transmission from one person to anothermade, worn, handled and disposed of properly.ldquoTherefore, on balance, we are recommending to the people of Wales that three-layer face-coverings should be used in situations where social distancing measures can be more dficult to achieve, for example, on public transport."We are not recommending their use outdoors.ldquoThe wearing of face coverings will not be mandatory, but we will encourage people to do this for the benefit of themselves and others.Mr Gething stressed that this advice only applies to people who are not showing symptoms of coronavirus, adding: ldquoAnyone who has a high temperature, a new, continuous cough or a loss or change to their sense of smell or taste must self-isolate for a minimum of seven days and get a test as quickly as possible. Unless the test shows a negative result, people must not go out during this time, even with a face covering or mask. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA PENARTH boutique owner has raised enough money through online bingo nights with her customers to donate air conditioning units to a nearby hospice.Jodie Tanner, owner of The Queen B Boutique in the town, set up the Bonkers Bingo sessions via Zoom to provide some fun for her customers during lockdown.Across two weeks, the bingo sessions raised pound, for the charity, which was chosen by each of the weeks winners.ldquoSo many people come into the shop for a chat when we werenrsquot in lockdown, and I could see that the mental wellbeing of so many was low during lockdown, so I just went from there really and put something together to provide some fun, she said.ldquoWe didnrsquot have a theme in the first week, but then after that wersquove had a theme every week ndash the first week it was rollers, even the men were wearing them, andpeople didnrsquot have rollers, they were wearing toilet rolls.ldquoThe following week we had all kinds of hats.Prizes are given out throughout the night, and the winner of the final game is able to select a charity to win the funds raised that evening.The Marie Curie Hospice, Cardf and the Vale in Bridgeman Road was nominated two weeks in a row.The pound, raised in those two weeks went towards mobile air conditioning units for the single rooms in the hospice - which provides round-the-clock expert end of le care.Hospice manager Sarah Lloyd-Davies said: ldquoWe are so grateful to Jodie and all her customers ndash many of whom are local to us - for raising these funds and donating these units.ldquoIt will make such a dference in the warm weather to patients in our single rooms.ldquoThank you to all who have made this possible.Marie Curiersquos fundraising activity has been devastated as part of the national coronavirus response.The charity urgently needs funding to make certain that they can continue to provide services and keep doctors, nurse and hospice staff on the frontline, supporting dying people with and without coronavirus.If you can help, donate online at mariecurie.org.uk emergency or Text NURSE to . article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA FAIRTRADE coffee farmer who visited Penarth during Fairtrade Fortnight, has spoken of the plight of rural communities during lockdown in Uganda.Three months ago, Jenipher Wetaka Sambazi, a Fairtrade coffee farmer from the Mt Elgon region in Uganda, was sharing her experiences of the benefit of Fairtrade in Penarthrsquos Tabernacle Baptist Church.More NewsVictory in campaign to save Dinas Powys ancient woodland as dam plan is abandonedVale nurse developed coronavirus symptoms after sitting with patient, inquest toldPenarth RNLI station marks  years despite current coronavirus lockdownNow she and her family, like communities around the world, are under lockdown.In March, campaigners, businesses, supporters, and students from around Wales heard Jenipherrsquos story, face to face.Now she is unable to travel or even meet with her neighbours.This means the coffee picked at the end of the last harvest remains on the mountain and Jenipher and her fellow farmers are prohibited from travelling to gather it for processing under the current lockdown rules.There are currently several hundred known cases of covid- in Uganda, but none in the Mount Elgon region and no fatalities in Uganda as yet.Farmers want to keep it this way, but lockdown is causing other concerns such as limiting access to food and healthcare.This is the time of year when there is the least amount of food available, and the closing of markets and freedom to travel for farmers to source food and water means that times are exceptionally hard.Jenipher as vice-chairwoman of a Fairtrade coffee cooperative, is responsible for many who rely on the cooperative for work.The expert hand-sorters who are seasonal workers and rely on this part of the coffee chain to feed their family at this time, have no coffee to sort.While they may have some spare eggs, vegetables or matoke to trade, the threat of soldiers prohibiting them from doing so is too much for them.Farmer co-operatives, an essential element of Fairtrade, enable and encourage communities to work together.Fairtrade also requires an extra amount of money, the Fairtrade premium, to be paid to producers.Fairtrade farmers like Jenipher are struggling, but they have the benefits of a strong local community as well as the backup of the Fairtrade premium.Fairtrade International have announced a .m euro Fairtrade Producer Relief fund targeting the immediate needs and Resilience Fund to help producers rebuild their businesses after Covid-.Jenipher Wettaka Sambazi said: ldquoLe is hard.ldquoThe markets are shut so there is nowhere to sell or earn money, or to buy food and basic essentials.ldquoLocal health centres have been shut to reduce the chance of spreading the virus, but since all transport is banned, those who need operations, treatment or antenatal care need to walk  km to the nearest hospital.ldquoTwo women and their unborn babies have died on the way."Roger Casey, who attends Tabernacle Baptist Church said: ldquoIt was wonderful to meet Jenipher and hear her story.ldquoWe get through a lot of coffee in our office and meeting a real coffee farmer from Uganda makes you think about the real people and real lives behind that Fairtrade logo.Vale MS Jane Hutt said: ldquoMeeting Jenipher during her visit to Wales earlier this year was inspiring.ldquoThe increasing dficulties facing rural farming communities because of the pandemic has shown how important Fairtrade cooperatives continue to be and I am glad that leaders like Jenipher continue to promote the benefits of Fairtrade and to support communities.National co-ordinator of Fair Trade Wales, Aileen Burmeister added: ldquoFair Trade producers are being impacted by covid- restrictions.ldquoGlobal stock markets are falling, meaning that farmers and workers are receiving far less for their produce."It is in these times that we can really see how important the Fairtrade minimum price is. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey story: Penarth RNLI  - before lockdown " Penarth RNLI celebrates th anniversary - virtuallyPenarth RNLI station. Pic: Penarth RNLI leboat helm, Ben Evans" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentCREW and supporters of Penarth RNLI are set to celebrate the leboat stationrsquos milestone anniversary.Current covid- lockdown restrictions mean the station is closed, but to mark the official day of reopening, at am on the Wednesday, June  the stationrsquos Facebook followers are invited to a live online QA session.It is hoped that people will be able to share their memories of the leboat and the contribution that the station has made to the local community.Additional events to mark the history of the leboat in Penarth will be promoted throughout the year once lockdown eases.MORE STORIESPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandPenarths RNLI crew on the hunt for new membersPenarthrsquos affiliation with the RNLI first started in , in  the station was closed.However, following a highly successful public campaign an RNLI station was re-established in .The new leboat was housed in a local private garages, but soon a better lsquostationrsquo was developed in the deckchair storebefore moving to its current home, a purpose built station opened in .Gareth Wigmore, one of the first crew members in  and now station president said the leboat was pushed by the crew along the seafront, which at the time wasnrsquot even one way.ldquoWe were as keen as mustard, pleased to be doing our bit for the community, but we had rudimentary equipment back then, he said.ldquoSome of our protective equipment was made by the local community.Crew member Karl Lawrence, with  yearsrsquo experience with the RNLI, said: ldquoThe best part of le-boating is working well as a team.ldquoWe maintain this team spirit by regularly exercising and training both ashore and afloat.ldquoSince opening our new station at the south end of the Esplanade we have installed a training room which is ideal for providing training in a warm, well-lit and stable room, prior to practicing on often rough seas in the leboats.ldquoMy favourite rsquoshoutsrsquo are oddly those which occur in the early hours of the morning on a spring day.ldquoBy the time the job has been completed and the boats are washed down and prepared again for service, we gather on our balcony drinking tea or coffee, watching the sun rise and exchanging with each other our plans for the day ahead, before most other people have woken up.Celebrating the success of the station, current leboat operations manager, Jason Dunlop said ldquoI am incredibly proud to celebrate the stationrsquos -year anniversary.ldquoIt is testament to the community of Penarth who have supported the leboats by providing volunteers, funds, and ongoing support.ldquoThis community effort over the past  years has saved  lives, we have rescued or aided  people and our leboats have launched on service  times.ldquoHundreds of volunteers have supported the RNLI and the station in this time.ldquoI would like to express my thanks to them all and their families.He added: ldquoIt makes no dferencethe role people have played is to crew the boats, to assist launch on shore, provide community safety advice, run our shops or fundraise, everyone plays a vital role in saving story: Latest figures show that more than , grants have been paid to companies across the retail, leisure, and hospitality sector whose property has a rateable value of pound, or less.These businesses are also benefitting from rates relief through the pound.bn package announced in March.More NewsPenarth RNLI celebrates th anniversary - title: zoos reopen visitors first time since lockdown
story: Zoos and safari parks have been allowed to open their doors to visitors from Monday, as part of efforts to begin reopening the economy, as long as they have implemented social distancing and other safety measures.Long queues of people formed outside ZSL London Zoo in Regentrsquos Park, west London, ahead of the parkrsquos reopening for the first time since late March.Parents and children were asked to respect two-metre social distancing and many wore face coverings.Kathryn England, chief operating officer for ZSL London Zoo, said that it was ldquoglorious to be able to welcome customers back to the park.ldquoItrsquos been really quiet here so to be able to seecoming back with absolutely enormous smiles all over their faces really is a special moment for us all here, she said.ldquoWersquove really reconfigured the whole zoo so that people feel and are safehelliptherersquos lots of signage around to remind them to keep a lionrsquosapart, a tigerrsquosapart.Our gorillas are celebrating our reopening today with a colourful addition to their enclosure! Were all so excited that our efforts have paid off and we can finally welcome you back. Find out everything you need to know about visiting us here: https:t.co ThlSQFGT pic vsBXxRCmdash ZSL London ZooJune , Ms England added that the high demand for tickets showed an immense support from the public, which she described as ldquototally moving.ldquoItrsquos so nice to see children beside themselves with excitement and parents relieved to be able to have a dferent place to come and entertain the children for a few hours, she said.ldquoWhatrsquos also nice is that the staff are absolutely thrilled to have people back, itrsquos great.Other zoos such as Chester Zoo were also welcoming people back from Monday, while some attractions are planning to open their doors again in the coming weeks.Animal and wildle venues were given the green light to reopen outdoor areas of their sites by the Government last week, after many raised concerns they were facing a financial crisis.The conservation work many zoos carry out around the world, which is often largely funded by visitors to the attractions, was also at risk, they warned.But the reopening has come too late for some sites, with Living Coasts attraction in Torquay, Devon, announcing it would close for good as a title: reliable approach easing lockdown best economy first minister says
story: Mark Drakeford said unlocking ldquotoo much too soon would ultimately lead to a clampdown on freedoms for a second time,coronavirus started circulating across the country again.On Monday Mr Drakeford defended his governmentrsquos conservative easing of measures compared with England, despite signs the virus is declining faster in Wales, after critics said his approach could worsen the economic impact of Covid-.The spread of coronavirus continues to slow in Wales.Thanks to your actions, we have some headroom to make further changes to the lockdown regulations this week.We will continue to make changes in a careful and cautious way, based on the latest scientic evidence. pic YFqzmYHbDKmdash Mark DrakefordJune , It came as Public Health Wales said a further four people had died after testing positive for the virus, taking its total number of deaths to ,, while the total number of cases increased by  to ,.Responding to the suggestion that the risk to public health and the economy were being balanced, Mr Drakeford told the daily press briefing in Cardf: ldquoI have never seen the needs of health and the needs of the economy as being opposite sides of the scales, where to do the right thing by one is to do harm to the other.ldquoI am with those very many economists who argue that a reliable move out of lockdown in which we do not take the risk of coronavirus circulating again is the best for the economy as well.ldquoNothing would be worse for the economy than a stop-start approach in which we do too much too soon, lead to coronavirus in rapid circulation and a clampdown on everything for a second time.ldquoMuch better for the economy that we take a reliable and predictable path out of coronavirus that safeguards peoplersquos health and is good for the economy as well.ldquoThose two things have always got to be together.An announcement on what will be relaxed next in Wales will be made on Friday, which is expected to include reopening non-essential shops and relaxing restrictions on more outdoor activities.The latest number of confirmed cases of Coronavirus in Wales has been updated.Data dashboard:# https:t.co zpWRYSUbfh# https:t.co HSclxpZjBhFind out how we are responding to the spread of the virus in our daily statement here: https:t.co uSKHzzsG pic gnKlDdeDnvmdash Public Health WalesJune , But Plaid Cymrursquos Helen Mary Jones urged the Welsh Government to give more guidance to employers who faced economic damagerestrictions continued, while the Welsh Conservativesrsquo Darren Millar MS said businesses faced going ldquobustprevented from reopening after the next review.Mr Drakeford also defended his governmentrsquos decision to stick with the two-metre social distancing rule, despite concerns from businesses who say their ability to trade will be curbed with it in place.A UK Government review is currently looking into whether the rule can be reduced in England, with Chancellor Rishi Sunak saying a shorter distance could have an ldquoenormous impact on the ability of businesses to make profit.ldquoThe advice from Sagehas been that the two-metre rule remains an essential safeguard.ldquoAs you halve the distance that people can be together you double the risk coronavirus will spread between them, Mr Drakeford said.ldquoWe will follow the review very carefully of course. If the scientic advice changes, then we will change our policy in Wales.If you have #Coronavirus symptoms, you should self-isolate for at least  days and get a test as soon as possible.You should not leave your home during this time, evenyou use a face mask.https:t.co eVrIIxWBD pic EUGUcXkmdash Dr Frank AthertonJune , When askedthere was a chance Wales could reduce the distance without the change being endorsed by Walesrsquo chief medical officer, Frank Atherton, Mr Drakeford said he ldquocould not be categorical about that.He added: ldquoThe scientic advice is, in the end, one strand of everything we have to weigh up.ldquoBut for me it is a very important strand, and I certainly wouldnrsquot be saying today that we would in any way likely depart from it.Mr Drakeford told the press conference that contact with the UK Government had come to a ldquostop, with almost three weeks having passed since he last spoke to Prime Minister Boris Johnson.There had been no discussions with UK ministers, with the exception of Welsh Secretary Simon Hart, since then, he said, though there had been contact between officials.ldquoIn terms of what I have wanted to see, that regular reliable rhythm of meetings with UK ministers, and the stop-start arrangements wersquove had, Irsquom afraid wersquove been in a stop part of that cycle for more than two weeks, he said.Mr Drakeford also said he was ldquovery unattracted to the idea of putting a ban on people from England entering Wales in futurethe dference between the countriesrsquo current R numbers remained the same or worsened across title: expert tells peers very surprised uk avoided second wave
story: The House of Lords Science and Technology Committee heard that countries like China and Iran have experienced second waves of the outbreak, and that Hong Kong is nearing its third wave.Sir John Bell, regius professor of medicine at the University of Oxford, told the committee that with lockdown restrictions easing, it is likely the UK will also see aof the Covid- epidemic.He said: ldquoI think it is possible that we might not have a second wave.ldquoBut I think given the fact that the lockdown has now been largely released, wersquore now back in action, and we have still, pretty rapidly declining, but a pretty reasonable level of infections in the community, I would be very surprisedwe avoided the second wave.Sir John added that this posed two questions.This would be whether there would be a number of single outbursts around the country, and then a second wave, orthe UK was just going to get a second wave and when..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Expert tells peers he would be  uvery surprised uUK avoided second wave article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
